title-group.article-title: Open-closed homotopy algebra in superstring field theory

contrib.aff: Center for Gravitational Physics and Quantum Information, Yukawa Institute for Theoretical Physics , Kyoto University, Kitashirakawa Oiwakecho, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606-8502, Japan

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: We construct open-closed superstring interactions based on the open-closed homotopy algebra structure. This provides a classical open superstring field theory on general closed-superstring-field backgrounds described by classical solutions of the nonlinear equation of motion of the closed superstring field theory. We also give the corresponding WZW-like action through the map connecting the homotopy-based and WZW-like formulations.

institution-wrap.institution: Japan Society for the Promotion of Science

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: It is known that several homotopy algebras are naturally realized as algebraic structures in string field theories and play a significant role. This was first recognized in closed bosonic string field theory [ 1 , 2 ], where the L ∞ structure determines the (classical) gauge-invariant action. Open bosonic string field theory was first formulated as a cubic theory using the (Witten) associative product [ 3 ] but can be extended to that with an A ∞ structure more generally [ 4 , 5 ]. This is also deformed to the theory on general closed string backgrounds [ 6–8 ] based on the open-closed homotopy algebra (OCHA) structure [ 9–11 ]. In the superstring field theories, the homotopy algebra structure is more important. Since it seems inevitable to avoid associativity anomaly [ 12 ], the A ∞ structure becomes essential to determine the gauge-invariant action in the open superstring field theory [ 13–15 ]. The L ∞ structure again plays the role of guiding principle to determine the action with appropriate picture numbers in the heterotic and type II superstring field theories [ 16–20 ].

On the other hand, the current understanding is that there is no essential difference between the theory of an open string/closed string mixed system and the theory of a purely closed string. It merely describes the perturbation on the different backgrounds, those with and without a D-brane [ 21 , 22 ]. They should be derived from a non-perturbatively formulated fundamental theory such as string field theory, but it is not a priori clear which one should be considered more fundamental. The closed string field theory is simpler, but the open-closed string field theory has a larger symmetry structure, the OCHA structure.
1
The purpose of this paper is to construct an open-closed string field theory realizing the OCHA structure. The action obtained explains the classical open string field theory on general closed-string backgrounds.

The paper is organized as follows. In Sect. 2 , we briefly review the open superstring field theory with general A ∞ structure. After introducing some conventions and fundamental ingredients, we show how we construct the open superstring field theory based on the A ∞ structure. The superstring products with appropriate picture numbers satisfying the A ∞ relations can be obtained by recursively solving the differential equations. We similarly review the closed superstring field theory with the L ∞ structure in Sect. 3 . We define the string products multiplying both open and closed string field in Sect. 4 and show the relations they must satisfy to form the OCHA. We also give the differential equations that products with the OCHA structure should follow. They provide an action of the open superstring field theory on the general closed superstring backgrounds. In Sect. 5 , we obtain, as a by-product, the corresponding WZW-like action through the map connecting the homotopy-based and WZW-like formulations, which is a generalization considered in Ref. [ 24 ]. Section 6 is devoted to the summary and discussion. In order to help the construction of concrete string interactions, some explicit procedure for solving the differential equastions in given in Appendix A . Appendix B was added to make the paper self-contained. We introduce two composite string fields, the pure-gauge open string field and the associated open string field, which is nontrivial in the theory with general A ∞ structure.

sec.title: Open superstring field theory with A ∞ structure
sec.p: We summarize in this section how the open superstring field theory is constructed based on the A ∞ algebra structure.

sec.title: Open superstring field
sec.p:
The first-quantized Hilbert space of an open superstring is composed of two sectors:
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o} = \mathcal {H}_\mathrm{NS} + \mathcal {H}_\mathrm{R}$
. Correspondingly, the open superstring field Ψ has two components: Ψ = Ψ NS + Ψ R , both of which are Grassmann odd and have ghost number 1. The component Ψ NS (Ψ R ) has picture number −1 (−1/2) and represents space-time bosons (fermions). We impose on it the constraint
(1)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {P}^\mathrm{o}_{XY}\Psi = \Psi ,\qquad \mathcal {P}^\mathrm{o}_{XY} = \mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o}(\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o})^{-1}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
with
(2)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o} = \pi ^0 + X^\mathrm{o}\pi ^1,\qquad (\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o})^{-1} = \pi ^0 + Y^\mathrm{o}\pi ^1, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where π 0 and π 1 are the projection operators onto the NS and R components, respectively: π 0 Ψ = Ψ NS and π 1 Ψ = Ψ R . The picture-changing operator (PCO) of the open superstring X o and its inverse Y o are defined by
(3)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} X^\mathrm{o} = -\delta (\beta _0)G + (\gamma _0\delta (\beta _0)+\delta (\beta _0)\gamma _0)b_0,\qquad Y^\mathrm{o} = - \frac{G}{L_0}\delta (\gamma _0). \end{eqnarray*} $$
The PCO X o is BRST exact in the large Hilbert space:
(4)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} X^\mathrm{o}=[Q,\Xi ^\mathrm{o}],\qquad \Xi ^\mathrm{o} = \xi _0 + (\Theta (\beta _0)\eta \xi _0-\xi _0)P_{-3/2} + (\xi _0\eta \Theta (\beta _0)-\xi _0)P_{-1/2}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where P −3/2 ( P −1/2 ) is the projection operator onto the states with picture number −3/2 (−1/2). We call the Hilbert space restricted by the constraint in Eq. ( 1 ) the restricted Hilbert space and denote it as
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res}$
. Note that
$\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o}$
and
$(\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o})^{-1}$
satisfy
(5)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o}(\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o})^{-1}\mathcal {G}^0 = \mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o},\qquad (\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o})^{-1}\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o}(\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o})^{-1} = (\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o})^{-1},\qquad [Q,\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o}] = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
and thus
$\mathcal {P}^\mathrm{o}_{XY}$
is a projection operator that is compatible with the BRST cohomology:
$Q\mathcal {P}^\mathrm{o}_{XY}=\mathcal {P}^\mathrm{o}_{XY}Q\mathcal {P}^\mathrm{o}_{XY}$
. The open superstring field satisfying Eq. ( 1 ) is expanded in the ghost zero-modes as
(6)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Psi = (\phi _\mathrm{NS} - c_0\psi _\mathrm{NS}) + \left(\phi _\mathrm{R}-\frac{1}{2}(\gamma _0+c_0G)\psi _\mathrm{R}\right)\ \in \mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
The natural symplectic forms
$\omega _s^o$
and Ω o in
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}$
and
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res}$
, respectively, are defined by using the BPZ inner product as
(7)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \omega _\mathrm{s}^\mathrm{o}(\Psi _1,\Psi _2) = (-1)^{\textrm {deg}(\Psi _1)}\langle \Psi _1|\Psi _2\rangle , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(8)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Omega ^\mathrm{o}(\Psi _1,\Psi _2) = (-1)^{\textrm {deg}(\Psi _1)}\langle \Psi _1|(\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o})^{-1}|\Psi _2\rangle , \end{eqnarray*} $$
where deg(Ψ) = 1 or 0 if Ψ is Grassmann even or odd, respectively. We also use a natural symplectic form
$\omega _l^o$
in the large Hilbert space
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{l}^\mathrm{o}$
, which is similarly defined using the BPZ inner product in
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{l}^\mathrm{o}$
, and related to
$\omega _s^o$
as
$\omega _l^o(\xi _0\Psi _1,\Psi _2)=\omega _s^o(\Psi _1,\Psi _2)$
if
$\Psi _1,\Psi _2\in \mathcal {H}_\mathrm{s}^\mathrm{o}$
.

sec.title: Interaction with A ∞ structure
sec.p:
Open superstring interactions are described by the string products
M n
mapping n open superstring fields to an open superstring field as
(9)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} &&M_n\ :\qquad \qquad (\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res})^{\otimes n} \longrightarrow \mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res},\qquad (n\ge 1),\nonumber \\ &&\rm{\in} \qquad \qquad {\in}\\ &&\Psi _1 \otimes \ \cdots \otimes \Psi _n \qquad \longmapsto \qquad M_n(\Psi _1,\ \ldots , \Psi _n). \end{eqnarray*} $$
We identify the one-string product as the open superstring BRST operator: M 1 = Q o . Note that the conditions
(10)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {P}^\mathrm{o}_{XY}M_n(\Psi _1,\ldots ,\Psi _n) = M_n(\Psi _1,\ldots ,\Psi _n) \end{eqnarray*} $$
hold by definition. The multi-linear maps
M n
further satisfy the A ∞ relations
(11)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \sum _{m=0}^n\sum _{k=0}^{n-m} (-1)^{\epsilon (1,k)} M_{n-m+1}(\Psi _1,\ldots ,\Psi _k, M_{m+1}(\Psi _{k+1},\ldots ,\Psi _{k+m+1}),\Psi _{k+m+2},\ldots ,\Psi _n) = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where
$\epsilon (1,k)=\sum _{i=1}^k\textrm {deg}(\Psi _i)$
, and cyclicity with respect to the symplectic form Ω o ,
(12)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Omega ^\mathrm{o}(\Psi _1,M_n(\Psi _2,\ldots ,\Psi _{n+1})) = -(-1)^{\textrm {deg}(\Psi _1)}\Omega ^\mathrm{o}(M_n(\Psi _1,\ldots ,\Psi _n),\Psi _{n+1}). \end{eqnarray*} $$
The linear maps satisfying Eqs. ( 11 ) and ( 12 ) form the cyclic A ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res},\Omega ^\mathrm{o},\lbrace M_m\rbrace )$
.

Coalgebra representation allows us to describe the infinite number of relations of maps
M n
concisely [ 25 ]. The set of maps {
M n
} are represented by a degree-odd coderivation
$\boldsymbol{M}=\sum _{n=1}^\infty \boldsymbol{M}_{n}$
acting on the tensor algebra
$\mathcal {TH}_\mathrm{o}=\sum _{n=0}^\infty (\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res})^{\otimes n}$
as
(13)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{M} = \sum _{n=1}^\infty \ \boldsymbol{M}_n = \sum _{n=1}^\infty \sum _{k,l=0}^\infty \left(\mathbb {I}^{\otimes k}\otimes M_n\otimes \mathbb {I}^{\otimes l} \right)\pi ^\mathrm{o}_{k+n+l}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where
$\pi _m^\mathrm{o}$
is the projection operator onto
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res})^{\otimes m}\subset \mathcal {TH}_\mathrm{o}$
. Then the A ∞ relations in Eq. ( 11 ) are concisely written as
2
(14)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{M},\boldsymbol{M}] = 0. \end{eqnarray*} $$
For open superstring field theory, the string interaction
M n
must be defined for each combination of NS and R inputs so that the picture number must be conserved:
3
(15)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{M}_{n+1} = \sum _{p+r=n}\boldsymbol{M}_{p+r+1}^{(p)}\big|_{2r}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where p is the picture number that the the map itself has and 2 r is the Ramond number (= number of Ramond inputs − number of Ramond outputs).

The action with A ∞ structure is given by
(16)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} I_\mathrm{o} = \int _0^1dt\, \Omega ^\mathrm{o}\left(\Psi ,\pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{M}\left(\frac{1}{1-t\Psi }\right)\right), \end{eqnarray*} $$
where we introduce a real parameter t ∈ [0, 1] and the group-like element
$\frac{1}{1-\Psi }$
defined by
(17)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \frac{1}{1-\Psi } = \mathbb {I}_{\mathcal {TH}_\mathrm{o}}+\sum _{n=1}^\infty \Psi ^{\otimes n}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Here,
$\mathbb {I}_{\mathcal {TH}_\mathrm{o}}$
is the identity in
$\mathcal {TH}_o$
satisfying
$\mathbb {I}_{\mathcal {TH}_\mathrm{o}}\otimes V = V = V\otimes \mathbb {I}_{\mathcal {TH}_\mathrm{o}}$
for all
$V\in \mathcal {TH}_\mathrm{o}$
. The arbitrary variation of I o is given by
(18)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \delta I_\mathrm{o} = \Omega ^\mathrm{o}\left(\delta \Psi ,\pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{M}\left(\frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right)\right), \end{eqnarray*} $$
where we used the cyclicity in Eq. ( 12 ). We can show that the action in Eq. ( 16 ) is invariant under the gauge transformation
(19)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \delta _{\Lambda }\Psi = \pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{M}\left(\frac{1}{1-\Psi }\otimes \Lambda \otimes \frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right), \end{eqnarray*} $$
using the A ∞ relation in Eq. ( 11 ) and cyclicity in Eq. ( 12 ):
(20)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \delta _{\Lambda }I_\mathrm{o} &=& \Omega ^\mathrm{o}\left(\pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{M}\left(\frac{1}{1-\Psi }\otimes \Lambda \otimes \frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right), \pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{M}\left(\frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right)\right) \nonumber \\ &=&\Omega ^\mathrm{o}\left(\Lambda , \pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{M}\left(\frac{1}{1-\Psi }\otimes \pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{M}\left(\frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right)\otimes \frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right)\right) \nonumber \\ &=&\Omega ^\mathrm{o}\left(\Lambda ,\pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{MM}\left(\frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right)\right) = 0. \end{eqnarray*} $$

sec.title: Explicit construction of interactions
sec.p:
The cyclic A ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res},\Omega ^\mathrm{o},\boldsymbol{M})$
for open superstring field theory is constructed in two steps. First, we consider a cyclic A ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_l^o,\omega _l^o,\boldsymbol{Q}-\boldsymbol{\eta }+\boldsymbol{A})$
. A degree-odd coderivation
(21)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{A}=\sum _{p,r=0}^\infty \boldsymbol{A}_{p+r+1}^{(p)}\big|^{2r}\qquad (\boldsymbol{A}_1^{(0)}\big| ^0\equiv 0) \end{eqnarray*} $$
is defined respecting the cyclic Ramond number (= number of Ramond inputs + number of Ramond outputs) to make it easier to realize cyclicity.
4
This other A ∞ algebra can be decomposed into two mutually commutative A ∞ algebras
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{l},\boldsymbol{\mathcal {D}})$
and
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{l},\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}})$
with
(22)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\boldsymbol{\mathcal {D}} = \pi _1\boldsymbol{Q} +\pi _1^0\boldsymbol{A},\qquad \pi _1\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}} = \pi _1\boldsymbol{\eta } -\pi _1^1\boldsymbol{A} \end{eqnarray*} $$
depending on the picture number deficit of the output. The A ∞ relation
$[\boldsymbol{A},\boldsymbol{A}]=0$
can also be decomposed as
(23a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{A}] + \frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{A},\boldsymbol{A}]^1 = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(23b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{A}] - \frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{A},\boldsymbol{A}]^2 = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where the bracket with subscript
$[\cdot ,\cdot ]^{1\, \textrm {or}\, 2}$
is defined by projecting the intermediate state onto the NS or R state after taking the (graded) commutator. The relation [ ·, ·] = [ ·, ·] 1 + [ ·, ·] 2 holds since the intermediate state is either the NS state or R state. If such A ∞ algebras are obtained, we can transform them by the cohomomorphism
(24)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \hat{\boldsymbol{F}}^{-1} = \pi _1\mathbb {I}- \Xi ^\mathrm{o}\pi _1^1\boldsymbol{A} \end{eqnarray*} $$
to the cyclic A ∞ algebra of interest
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res},\Omega ^\mathrm{o},\boldsymbol{M})$
and a (trivial) A ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}^\mathrm{o}_\mathrm{l},\boldsymbol{\eta })$
:
(25)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\hat{\boldsymbol{F}}^{-1}\boldsymbol{\mathcal {D}}\hat{\boldsymbol{F}} = \pi _1\boldsymbol{Q} + \mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o}\pi _1\boldsymbol{A}\hat{\boldsymbol{F}}\ \equiv \ \pi _1\boldsymbol{M},\qquad \pi _1\hat{\boldsymbol{F}}^{-1}\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}}\hat{\boldsymbol{F}} = \pi _1\boldsymbol{\eta }. \end{eqnarray*} $$

We consider a generating function
(26)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{A}(s,t) = \sum _{p,m,r=0}^\infty s^mt^p\boldsymbol{A}_{m+p+r+1}^{(p)}\big|^{2r}\ \equiv \ \sum _{p=0}^\infty t^p \boldsymbol{A}^{(p)}(s) \end{eqnarray*} $$
for constructing the A ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_l^o,\omega _l^o,\boldsymbol{Q}-\boldsymbol{\eta }+\boldsymbol{A})$
and extend the A ∞ relations in Eqs. (23) to
(27a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{I}(s,t)\ \equiv \ [\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{A}(s,t)] + \frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{A}(s,t),\boldsymbol{A}(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(27b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{J}(s,t)\ \equiv \ [\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{A}(s,t)] - \frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{A}(s,t),\boldsymbol{A}(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_2(t)} = 0 \end{eqnarray*} $$
by introducing parameters s and t counting the picture number deficit and the picture number, respectively. Here, in Eqs. (27),
$\mathfrak {o}_1(s) = \pi ^0+s\pi ^1,\ \mathfrak {o}_2(t) = t\pi ^1$
, and the bracket with subscript
$[\cdot ,\cdot ]_{\mathcal {O}}$
is another simple notation for [ ·, ·] 1, 2 and is defined by inserting the operator
$\mathcal {O}$
into the intermediate state after taking the (graded) commutation relation,
(28)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1[\boldsymbol{D},\boldsymbol{D}^{\prime }]_{\mathcal {O}} = \sum _n\pi _1\Big ( \boldsymbol{D}_n\big (\mathcal {O}\pi _1\boldsymbol{D}^{\prime }\wedge \mathbb {I}_{n-1}) -(-1)^{DD^{\prime }+\mathcal {O}(D+D^{\prime })}\boldsymbol{D}^{\prime }_n\big (\mathcal {O}\pi _1\boldsymbol{D}\wedge \mathbb {I}_{n-1}\big )\Big ). \end{eqnarray*} $$
At ( s, t ) = (0, 1), the generating function in Eq. ( 26 ) and the relations in Eqs. (27) reduce to
$\boldsymbol{A}(0,1)=\boldsymbol{A}$
and the A ∞ relations of Eqs. (23), respectively.

Then, we can show that if
$\boldsymbol{A}(s,t)$
satisfies the differential equations
(29a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _t\boldsymbol{A}(s,t) = [\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{\mu }(s,t)]+[\boldsymbol{A}(s,t),\boldsymbol{\mu }(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(29b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _s\boldsymbol{A}(s,t) = [\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{\mu }(s,t)] -[\boldsymbol{A}(s,t),\boldsymbol{\mu }(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_2(t)}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
introducing the degree-even coderivation
(30)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{\mu }(s,t) = \sum _{p,m,r=0}^\infty s^mt^p\boldsymbol{\mu }^{(p+1)}_{m+p+r+2}\big|^{2r}\ \equiv \ \sum _{p=0}^\infty t^p \boldsymbol{\mu }^{(p+1)}(s), \end{eqnarray*} $$
the t derivative of the left-hand sides of the relations in Eqs. (27) become
(31)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _t\boldsymbol{I}(s,t) = [\boldsymbol{I}(s,t),\boldsymbol{\mu }(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(32)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _t\boldsymbol{J}(s,t) = [\boldsymbol{J}(s,t),\boldsymbol{\mu }(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} -[\boldsymbol{I}(s,t),\boldsymbol{\mu }(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_2(s)} - \partial _s\boldsymbol{I}(s,t). \end{eqnarray*} $$
Thus, if
(33a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{I}(s,0) = [\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{A}(s,0)] + \frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{A}(s,0),\boldsymbol{A}(s,0)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(33b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{J}(s,0) = [\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{A}(s,0)] = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
then
$\boldsymbol{I}(s,t)=\boldsymbol{J}(s,t)=0$
. However, the relations in Eqs. (33) are nothing less than those satisfied by the geometric string products constructed similarly to those for the bosonic A ∞ algebra,
$\boldsymbol{Q} + \boldsymbol{M}_\mathrm{B}(s)$
, without any insertion:
(34)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{M}_\mathrm{B}(s)\ \equiv \ \sum _{m,r=0}^\infty s^m(\boldsymbol{M}_\mathrm{B})_{m+r+1}\big| ^{2r}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
We can obtain the cyclic A ∞ algebra,
$(\mathcal {H}_l^o,\omega _l^o,\boldsymbol{Q}-\boldsymbol{\eta }+\boldsymbol{A})$
by recursively solving the differential equations in Eqs. (29), or equivalently,
(35a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} (p+1)\boldsymbol{A}^{(p+1)}(s) = [\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{\mu }^{(p+1)}(s)] + \sum _{q=0}^p [\boldsymbol{A}^{(p-q)}(s),\boldsymbol{\mu }^{(q+1)}(s)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)}\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(35b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{\mu }^{(p+1)}(s)] &=&\partial _s\boldsymbol{A}^{(p)}(s) + \sum _{q=0}^{p-1}[\boldsymbol{A}^{(p-q-1)}(s),\boldsymbol{\mu }^{(q+1)}(s)]^2\, . \end{eqnarray*} $$
The second equation at p = 0 can be solved for
$\boldsymbol{\mu }^{(1)}(s)$
as
(36)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{\mu }^{(1)}(s) = \xi _0^\mathrm{o}\circ \partial _s\boldsymbol{M}_\mathrm{B}(s) \end{eqnarray*} $$
under the initial condition
$\boldsymbol{A}(s,0)=\boldsymbol{A}^{(0)}(s)=\boldsymbol{M}_\mathrm{B}(s)$
, where
$\xi_0^\mathrm{o}\,\circ$
is the operation defined on the general coderivation
$\boldsymbol{A}=\sum _{n=0}^\infty \boldsymbol{A}_{n+2}$
by
(37a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \xi _0^\mathrm{o}\circ \boldsymbol{A} = \sum _{n,k,l=0}^\infty \left(\mathbb {I}^{\otimes k}\otimes \left(\xi _0^\mathrm{o}\circ A_{n+2}\right)\otimes \mathbb {I}^{\otimes l} \right)\pi ^\mathrm{o}_{k+l+n+2} , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(37b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \xi _0^\mathrm{o}\circ A_{n+2} = \frac{1}{n+3}\left(\xi _0^\mathrm{o} A_{n+2} - (-1)^{\textrm {deg(A)}} \sum _{m=0}^{n+1} A_{n+2}\left(\mathbb {I}^{\otimes (n-m+1)}\otimes \xi _0^\mathrm{o}\otimes \mathbb {I}^{\otimes m}\right)\right) . \end{eqnarray*} $$
Substituting Eq. ( 36 ) into Eq. ( 35a ) at p = 0, we obtain
$\boldsymbol{A}^{(1)}(s)$
. Repeating the procedure, we can recursively obtain
$\boldsymbol{\mu }^{(p+1)}(s)$
and
$\boldsymbol{A}^{(n+1)}(s)$
from Eqs. ( 35b ) and (35a), respectively.
5
Then, finally, the cohomomorphism in Eq. ( 24 ) gives the cyclic A ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}^\mathrm{res}_\mathrm{o},\Omega ^\mathrm{o},\boldsymbol{M})$
.

sec.title: Closed superstring field theory with L ∞ structure
sec.p: Similarly to the open superstring field theory, closed (type II) superstring field theory is constructed based on the L ∞ algebra structure. We summarize it in this section.

sec.title: Closed superstring field
sec.p:
The first-quantized Hilbert space,
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}$
, of a type II (closed) superstring is composed of four sectors:
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c} = \mathcal {H}_{\mathrm{NS}\!-\!\mathrm{NS}} + \mathcal {H}_{\mathrm{R}\!-\!\mathrm{NS}} + \mathcal {H}_{\mathrm{NS}\!-\!\mathrm{R}} + \mathcal {H}_{\mathrm{R}\!-\!\mathrm{R}}$
. Correspondingly, the type II superstring field Φ has four components, Φ = Φ NS–NS + Φ R–NS + Φ NS–R + Φ R–R , all of which are Grassmann even and have ghost number 2. The components Φ NS–NS and Φ R–R have picture numbers (−1, −1) and (−1/2, −1/2), respectively, and represent space-time bosons. The components Φ R–NS and Φ NS–R have picture numbers (−1/2, −1) and (−1, −1/2), and represent space-time fermions. We impose closed string constraints,
(38)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} b_0^-\Phi = L_0^-\Phi = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
and also an extra constraint
(39)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {P}_{XY}^\mathrm{c}\Phi = \Phi ,\qquad \mathcal {P}_{XY}^\mathrm{c} = \mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c}(\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c})^{-1}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
with
(40)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c} = \pi ^{(0,0)} + X^\mathrm{c} \pi ^{(1,0)} + \bar{X}^\mathrm{c} \pi ^{(0,1)} + X^\mathrm{c}\bar{X}^\mathrm{c}\pi ^{(1,1)}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(41)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} (\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c})^{-1} = \pi ^{(0,0)} + Y^\mathrm{c} \pi ^{(1,0)} + \bar{Y}^\mathrm{c} \pi ^{(0,1)} + Y^\mathrm{c}\bar{Y}^\mathrm{c}\pi ^{(1,1)}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where π (0,0) , π (1,0) , π (0,1) , and π (1,1) , are the projection operators onto the NS–NS, R–NS, NS–R, and R–R components respectively: π (0,0) Φ = Φ NS–NS , π (1,0) Φ = Φ R–NS , π (0,1) Φ = Φ NS–R , and π (1,1) Φ = Φ R–R . The PCO X c
$(\bar{X}^\mathrm{c})$
and its inverse Y c
$(\bar{Y}^\mathrm{c})$
are defined by
(42)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} X^\mathrm{c} = -\delta (\beta _0)G + \frac{1}{2}(\gamma _0\delta (\beta _0)+\delta (\beta _0)\gamma _0)b^+_0,\qquad Y^\mathrm{c} = - 2\frac{G}{L^+_0}\delta (\gamma _0), \end{eqnarray*} $$
(43)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \bar{X}^\mathrm{c} = -\delta (\bar{\beta }_0)\bar{G} + \frac{1}{2} (\bar{\gamma }_0\delta (\bar{\beta }_0)+\delta (\bar{\beta }_0)\bar{\gamma }_0)b^+_0,\qquad \bar{Y}^\mathrm{c} = - 2\frac{\bar{G}}{L^+_0}\delta (\bar{\gamma }_0). \end{eqnarray*} $$
The PCOs X c and
$\bar{X}^\mathrm{c}$
are BRST exact in the large Hilbert space:
(44)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} X^\mathrm{c} = [Q,\Xi ^\mathrm{c}],\qquad \Xi ^\mathrm{c} = \xi _0 + (\Theta (\beta _0)\eta \xi _0-\xi _0)P_{-3/2}+(\xi _0\eta \Theta (\beta _0)-\xi _0)P_{-1/2}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(45)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \bar{X}^\mathrm{c} = [Q,\bar{\Xi }^\mathrm{c}],\qquad \bar{\Xi }^\mathrm{c} = \bar{\xi }_0 + (\Theta (\bar{\beta }_0)\bar{\eta }\bar{\xi }_0-\bar{\xi }_0)\bar{P}_{-3/2} +(\bar{\xi }_0\bar{\eta }\Theta (\bar{\beta }_0)-\bar{\xi }_0)\bar{P}_{-1/2}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where P −3/2 and P −1/2 (
$\bar{P}_{-3/2}$
and
$\bar{P}_{-1/2}$
) are the projectors onto the states with the left-moving (right-moving) picture numbers −3/2 and −1/2, respectively. We denote the restricted Hilbert space of the type II superstring as
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res}$
. Similarly to the relations in Eq. ( 5 ) for the open superstring,
$\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c}$
and
$(\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c})^{-1}$
satisfy the relations
(46)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c} (\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c})^{-1} \mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c} = \mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c},\qquad (\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c})^{-1}\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c} (\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c})^{-1} = (\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c})^{-1},\qquad [Q,\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c}] = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
and thus
$\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c}(\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c})^{-1}$
is a projector that is compatible with the BRST cohomology:
$Q\mathcal {P}_{XY}^\mathrm{c}=\mathcal {P}_{XY}^\mathrm{c}Q\mathcal {P}_{XY}^\mathrm{c}$
. The type II superstring field satisfying the constraint in Eq. ( 39 ) is expanded in the ghost zero-modes as
(47)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Phi &=& (\phi _{\mathrm{NS}\!-\!\mathrm{NS}}-c_0^+\psi _{\mathrm{NS}\!-\!\mathrm{NS}}) + \left(\phi _{\mathrm{R}\!-\!\mathrm{R}}-\frac{1}{2}(\gamma _0\bar{G}-\bar{\gamma }_0G +2c_0^+G\bar{G})\psi _{\mathrm{R}\!-\!\mathrm{R}}\right) \nonumber \\ &&+ \left(\phi _{\mathrm{R}\!-\!\mathrm{NS}}-\frac{1}{2}(\gamma _0+2c_0^+G)\psi _{\mathrm{R}\!-\!\mathrm{NS}}\right) + \left(\phi _{\mathrm{NS}\!-\!\mathrm{R}}-\frac{1}{2}(\bar{\gamma }_0+2c_0^+\bar{G})\psi _{\mathrm{NS}\!-\!\mathrm{R}}\right) \in \mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
The natural symplectic forms
$\omega _s^c$
and Ω c in
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}$
and
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res}$
, respectively, are defined by using the BPZ inner product as
(48)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \omega _\mathrm{s}^\mathrm{c}(\Phi _1,\Phi _2) = (-1)^{\Phi _1}\langle \Phi _1|c_0^-|\Phi _2\rangle , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(49)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Omega ^\mathrm{c}(\Phi _1,\Phi _2) = (-1)^{\Phi _1}\langle \Phi _1|c_0^-(\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c})^{-1}|\Phi _2\rangle . \end{eqnarray*} $$
The natural symplectic form
$\omega _l^c$
in the large Hilbert space
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{l}^\mathrm{c}$
is similarly defined by using the BPZ inner product in
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{l}^\mathrm{c}$
, and is related to
$\omega _s^c$
as
$\omega _l^c(\xi _0\bar{\xi }_0\Phi _1,\Phi _2)=\omega _s^c(\Phi _1,\Phi _2)$
if
$\Phi _1,\Phi _2\in \mathcal {H}_\mathrm{s}^\mathrm{c}$
.

sec.title: Interaction with L ∞ structure
sec.p:
Type II superstring interactions are described by the string products
L n
that map n closed superstring fields to a closed superstring field as
(50)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} &&L_n :\qquad\qquad (\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res})^{\wedge n} \longrightarrow \mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res},\qquad (n\ge 1), \nonumber \\ &&{\in} \qquad\qquad {\in} \nonumber\\ &&\Phi _1 \wedge \cdots \wedge \Phi _n \qquad \ \longmapsto \qquad L_n(\Phi _1,\ldots , \Phi _n), \end{eqnarray*} $$
where Φ 1 ∧ ⋅⋅⋅ ∧ Φ
n
is the symmetrized tensor product defined by
(51)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Phi _1\wedge \cdots \wedge \Phi _n = \sum _{\sigma }\Phi _{\sigma (1)}\otimes \cdots \otimes \Phi _{\sigma (n)}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
We identify the one-string product as the closed superstring BRST operator: L 1 = Q c . By definition, these products must satisfy
(52)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} b_0^-L_n(\Phi _1,\ldots ,\Phi _n) = L_0^-L_n(\Phi _1,\ldots ,\Phi _n) = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(53)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {P}_{XY}^\mathrm{c}L_n(\Phi _1,\ldots ,\Phi _n) = L_n(\Phi _1,\ldots ,\Phi _n). \end{eqnarray*} $$
We further impose the L ∞ relations
(54)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \sum _{\sigma } \sum _{m=1}^n (-1)^{\epsilon (\sigma )} \frac{1}{m!(n-m)!} L_{n-m+1}(L_m(\Phi _{\sigma (1)},\ldots ,\Phi _{\sigma (m)}),\Phi _{\sigma (m+1)},\ldots ,\Phi _{\sigma (n)}) = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
and cyclicity
(55)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Omega ^\mathrm{c}(\Phi _1,L_n(\Phi _2,\ldots ,\Phi _{n+1})) = -(-1)^{|\Phi _1|}\Omega ^\mathrm{c}(L_n(\Phi _1,\ldots ,\Phi _n),\Phi _{n+1}). \end{eqnarray*} $$
The linear maps satisfying Eqs. ( 54 ) and ( 55 ) form the cyclic L ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res},\Omega ^\mathrm{c},\lbrace L_m\rbrace )$
.

The linear maps in Eq. ( 50 ) are also represented by a degree-odd coderivation
$\boldsymbol{L}=\sum _{n=1}^\infty \boldsymbol{L}_n$
acting on the symmetrized tensor algebra
$\mathcal {SH}_\mathrm{c}=\sum _{n=0}^\infty (\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res})^{\wedge n}$
as
(56)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{L} = \sum _{n=1}^\infty \ \boldsymbol{L}_n = \sum _{n=1}^\infty \sum _{m=0}^\infty (L_n\wedge \mathbb {I}_m)\pi _{n+m}^\mathrm{c}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
with
$\mathbb {I}_m = \frac{1}{m!}\, \mathbb {I}^{\wedge m} =\ \mathbb {I}^{\otimes m},$
where
$\pi _m^\mathrm{c}$
is the projection operator onto
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res})^{\wedge m}\subset \mathcal {SH}_\mathrm{c}$
.

Then, the L ∞ relations in Eq. ( 54 ) are written as
(57)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{L},\boldsymbol{L}] = 0. \end{eqnarray*} $$

The string interaction
L n
of the type II superstring field theory must be defined for each combination of NS–NS, R–NS, NS–R, and R–R inputs so that the picture numbers of left- and right-moving sectors must be conserved separately:
(58)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{L}_{n+1} = \sum _{p+r=n}\sum _{\bar{p}+\bar{m}=n} \boldsymbol{L}^{(p,\bar{p})}_{p+r+1,\bar{p}+\bar{m}+1}\big| _{(2r,2\bar{r})}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where we used the diagonal matrix representation
$\boldsymbol{L}_{n,m}=\delta _{n,m}\boldsymbol{L}_n$
. The superscript p (
$\bar{p}$
) is the left-moving (right-moving) picture number that the map itself has, and the subscript 2 r (
$2\bar{r}$
) is the left-moving (right-moving) Ramond number.

Introducing a real parameter t ∈ [0, 1], the action with L ∞ structure is given by
(59)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} I_\mathrm{c} = \int ^1_0dt\, \Omega ^\mathrm{c}(\Phi ,\pi _1^\mathrm{c}\boldsymbol{L}(e^{\wedge t\Phi })), \end{eqnarray*} $$
with the group-like element
(60)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} e^{\wedge \Phi } = \mathbb {I}_{\mathcal {SH}_\mathrm{c}} + \sum _{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n!}\Phi ^{\wedge n}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where
$\mathbb {I}_{\mathcal {SH}_\mathrm{c}}$
is the identity in
$\mathcal {SH}_\mathrm{c}$
that satisfies
$\mathbb {I}_{\mathcal {SH}_\mathrm{c}}\wedge V=V$
for all
$V\in \mathcal {SH}_\mathrm{c}$
. The arbitrary variation of I c is given by
(61)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \delta I_\mathrm{c} = \Omega ^\mathrm{c}(\delta \Phi ,\pi _1\boldsymbol{L}(e^{\wedge \Phi })). \end{eqnarray*} $$
We can show the action in Eq. ( 59 ) is invariant under the gauge transformation
(62)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \delta _{\Lambda }\Phi = \pi _1^\mathrm{c}\boldsymbol{L}(e^{\wedge \Phi }\wedge \Lambda ), \end{eqnarray*} $$
using the L ∞ relation in Eq. ( 54 ) and cyclicity in Eq. ( 55 ):
(63)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \delta _{\Lambda } I_\mathrm{c} &=& \Omega ^\mathrm{c}\left(\pi _1^\mathrm{c}\boldsymbol{L}(e^{\wedge \Phi }\wedge \Lambda ), \pi _1^\mathrm{c}\boldsymbol{L}(e^{\wedge \Phi })\right) \nonumber \\ &=&\Omega ^\mathrm{c}\left(\Lambda ,\pi _1^\mathrm{c}\boldsymbol{L}\left(e^{\wedge \Phi }\wedge \pi _1^\mathrm{c}\boldsymbol{L}(e^{\wedge \Phi })\right)\right) \nonumber \\ &=&\Omega ^\mathrm{c}\left(\Lambda ,\pi _1^\mathrm{c}\boldsymbol{L}^2(e^{\wedge \Phi })\right) = 0. \end{eqnarray*} $$

sec.title: Explicit construction of interactions
sec.p:
The cyclic L ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res},\Omega ^\mathrm{c},\boldsymbol{L})$
is constructed in two steps. We consider first an L ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{l}^\mathrm{c},\boldsymbol{\mathcal {O}})$
with
(64)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\boldsymbol{\mathcal {O}} = \pi _1(\boldsymbol{Q} - \boldsymbol{\eta } - \bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }}+\boldsymbol{B}) -\left(1-\frac{1}{2}(X+\bar{X})\right)\pi _1^{(1,1)}\boldsymbol{B}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
introducing the degree-odd coderivation
(65)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{B}=\sum _{p,r=0}^\infty \sum _{\bar{p},\bar{r}=0}^\infty \boldsymbol{B}_{p+r+1,\bar{p}+\bar{r}+1}^{(p,\bar{p})}\big| ^{(2r,2\bar{r})}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
This L ∞ algebra is equivalent to three mutually commutative L ∞ algebras
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{l},\boldsymbol{\mathcal {D}})$
,
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{l},\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}})$
, and
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{l},\bar{\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}}})$
with
(66)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\boldsymbol{\mathcal {D}} = \pi _1\boldsymbol{Q}+\pi _1^{(0,0)}\boldsymbol{B}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(67)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}} = \pi _1\boldsymbol{\eta }-\left(\pi _1^{(1,0)} +\frac{1}{2}\bar{X}\pi _1^{(1,1)}\right)\boldsymbol{B},\qquad \pi _1\bar{\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}}} = \pi _1\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }}-\left(\pi _1^{(0,1)} +\frac{1}{2}X\pi _1^{(1,1)}\right)\boldsymbol{B}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
decomposed according to the picture number deficit. Then, the L ∞ relations are written as
(68a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{B}] + \frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{B},\boldsymbol{B}]^{11} = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(68b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{B}] -\frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{B},\boldsymbol{B}]^{21} -\frac{1}{4}[\boldsymbol{B},\boldsymbol{B}]_{\bar{X}}^{22} = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(68c)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }},\boldsymbol{B}] -\frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{B},\boldsymbol{B}]^{12} -\frac{1}{4}[\boldsymbol{B},\boldsymbol{B}]_{X}^{22} = 0. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Here, the bracket
$[\cdot ,\cdot ]^{11,21,12,22}$
is defined by projecting the intermediate state of the (graded) commutator to the NS–NS, R–NS, NS–R, or R–R state. We also define the bracket
$[\cdot ,\cdot ]^{22}_{X\, \textrm {or}\, \bar{X}}$
by further inserting X or
$\bar{X}$
at the intermediate R–R state. If such L ∞ algebras are found, we transform them by the cohomomorphism
(69)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\hat{\boldsymbol{F}}^{-1} = \pi _1\mathbb {I}-\left(\Xi \pi _1^{(1,0)}+\bar{\Xi }\pi ^{(0,1)}_1 +\frac{1}{2}(\Xi \bar{X}+X\bar{\Xi })\pi _1^{(1,1)}\right)\boldsymbol{B} \end{eqnarray*} $$
to the cyclic L ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res},\Omega ^\mathrm{c},\boldsymbol{L})$
and two (trivial) L ∞ algebras
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{l}^\mathrm{c},\boldsymbol{\eta })$
and
$(\mathcal {H}_l^c,\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }})$
as
(70)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\hat{\boldsymbol{F}}^{-1}\boldsymbol{\mathcal {D}}\hat{\boldsymbol{F}} = \pi _1\boldsymbol{Q}+\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c}\pi _1\boldsymbol{B}\hat{\boldsymbol{F}}\ \equiv \pi _1\boldsymbol{L}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(71)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\hat{\boldsymbol{F}}^{-1}\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}}\hat{\boldsymbol{F}} = \pi _1\boldsymbol{\eta },\qquad \pi _1\hat{\boldsymbol{F}}^{-1}\bar{\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}}}\hat{\boldsymbol{F}} = \pi _1\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Note that the L ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{l}^\mathrm{c},\boldsymbol{\mathcal {O}})$
is not cyclic , unlike the open superstring case. However, we can show, in a similar way to Appendix C of Ref. [ 18 ], that the
$\boldsymbol{L}$
in Eq. ( 70 ) is cyclic with respect to Ω c if
$\boldsymbol{B}$
is cyclic with respect to
$\omega _l^c$
.

In the next step, we consider the generating function
(72)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t) = \sum _{m,p,r=0}^\infty \sum _{\bar{m},\bar{p},\bar{r}=0}^\infty s^m\bar{s}^{\bar{m}}t^{p+\bar{p}}\boldsymbol{B}^{(p,\bar{p})}_{m+p+r+1,\bar{m}+\bar{p}+\bar{r}+1}\big| ^{(2r,2\bar{r})} \end{eqnarray*} $$
and extend the L ∞ relations in Eq. (68) to
(73a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{I}(s,\bar{s},t) &\equiv& [\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t)] + \frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t),\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1(s,\bar{s},t)} = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(73b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{J}(s,\bar{s},t) &\equiv& [\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t)] -\frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t),\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_2(t)} = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(73c)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \bar{\boldsymbol{J}}(s,\bar{s},t) &\equiv& [\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }},\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t)] -\frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t),\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\bar{\mathfrak {c}}_2(t)} = 0 \end{eqnarray*} $$
for constructing the L ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_l^c,\boldsymbol{\mathcal {O}})$
. The parameters s ,
$\bar{s}$
, and t count the left-moving picture number deficit, right-moving picture number deficit, and the total picture number, respectively. The bracket with subscript is defined by inserting
(74)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathfrak {c}_1(s,\bar{s},t) = \pi ^{(0,0)} +s\pi ^{(1,0)}+\bar{s}\pi ^{(0,1)} +\left(s\bar{s}+t(s\bar{X}+\bar{s}X)\right)\pi ^{(1,1)}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(75)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathfrak {c}_2(t) = t\pi ^{(1,0)}+\frac{t^2}{2}\bar{X}\pi ^{(1,1)},\qquad \bar{\mathfrak {c}}_2(t) = t\pi ^{(0,1)}+\frac{t^2}{2}X\pi ^{(1,1)} \end{eqnarray*} $$
at the intermediate state. At
$(s,\bar{s},t)=(0,0,1)$
, the generating function in Eq. ( 72 ) and the relations in Eq. (73) reduce to
$\boldsymbol{B}(0,0,1)=\boldsymbol{B}$
and the L ∞ relations in Eqs. (68), respectively.

We can show that if
$\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t)$
satisfies the differential equations
(76a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _t\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t) &=& [\boldsymbol{Q},(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,\bar{s},t)] \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, [\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1(s,\bar{s},t)} +\frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t),\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\mathfrak {d}(s,\bar{s})}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(76b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _s\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t) = [\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{\lambda }(s,\bar{s},t)] - [\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_2(t)}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(76c)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _{\bar{s}}\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t) = [\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }},\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}(s,\bar{s},t)] - [\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\bar{\mathfrak {c}}_2(t)}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
and
$[\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }},\boldsymbol{\lambda }(s,\bar{s})]=[\boldsymbol{\eta },\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}(s,\bar{s})]=0$
with
$\mathfrak {d}(s,\bar{s})=(s\bar{\Xi }+\bar{s}\Xi )\pi ^{(1,1)}$
and the degree-even coderivations
(77)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{\lambda }(s,\bar{s},t) = \sum _{m,p,r=0}^\infty \sum _{\bar{m},\bar{p},\bar{r}=0}^\infty s^m \bar{s}^{\bar{m}}t^{p+\bar{p}} \boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(p+1,\bar{p})}_{m+p+r+2,\bar{m}+\bar{p}+\bar{r}+1}\big| ^{(2r,2\bar{r})}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(78)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}(s,\bar{s},t) = \sum _{m,p,r=0}^\infty \sum _{\bar{m},\bar{p},\bar{r}=0}^\infty s^m\bar{s}^{\bar{m}}t^{p+\bar{p}} \bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(p,\bar{p}+1)}_{m+p+r+1,\bar{m}+\bar{p}+\bar{r}+2}\big| ^{(2r,2\bar{r})}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
the t derivative of the left-hand sides of the relations in Eqs. (73) become
(79a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _t\boldsymbol{I}(s,\bar{s},t) = [\boldsymbol{I}(s,\bar{s},t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1(s,\bar{s},t)} + [\boldsymbol{I}(s,\bar{s},t),\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\mathfrak {d}(s,\bar{s})}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(79b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _t\boldsymbol{J}(s,\bar{s},t) &=& [\boldsymbol{J}(s,\bar{s},t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1(s,\bar{s},t)} + [\boldsymbol{J}(s,\bar{s},t),\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\mathfrak {d}(s,\bar{s})} \nonumber \\ &&-\,\,\partial _s\boldsymbol{I}(s,\bar{s},t)- [\boldsymbol{I}(s,\bar{s},t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_2(t)}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(79c)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _t\bar{\boldsymbol{J}}(s,\bar{s},t) &=& [\bar{\boldsymbol{J}}(s,\bar{s},t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1(s,\bar{s},t)} + [\bar{\boldsymbol{J}}(s,\bar{s},t),\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\mathfrak {d}(s,\bar{s})} \nonumber \\ &&-\,\,\partial _{\bar{s}}\boldsymbol{I}(s,\bar{s},t)- [\boldsymbol{I}(s,\bar{s},t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\bar{\mathfrak {c}}_2(t)}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
They imply that if
(80a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{I}(s,\bar{s},0) = [\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},0)] + \frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},0),\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},0)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1(s,\bar{s},0)} = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(80b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{J}(s,\bar{s},0) = [\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},0)] = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(80c)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \bar{\boldsymbol{J}}(s,\bar{s},0) = [\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }},\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},0)] = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
then
$\boldsymbol{I}(s,\bar{s},t)=\boldsymbol{J}(s,\bar{s},t)=\bar{\boldsymbol{J}}(s,\bar{s},t)=0$
. The relations in Eqs. (80) are those satisfied by the geometric string product without any insertion, which can be constructed similarly to that for the bosonic L ∞ algebra,
$\boldsymbol{Q}+\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s})$
:
(81)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s})\ \equiv \ \sum _{m,r=0}^\infty \sum _{\bar{m},\bar{r}=0}^\infty s^m\bar{s}^{\bar{m}}(\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B})_{m+r+1,\bar{m}+\bar{r}+1}\big| ^{(2r,2\bar{r})}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Similar to the open superstring case in the previous section, we can obtain the L ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{l}^\mathrm{c},\boldsymbol{\mathcal {O}})$
by solving the differential equations in Eqs. (76) with the initial condition
(82)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},0)=\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s})\, . \end{eqnarray*} $$
The concrete procedures are slightly complicated, so Appendix A shows the lower-order results. The cohomomorphism in Eq. ( 69 ) gives the cyclic L ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res},\Omega ^\mathrm{c},\boldsymbol{L})$
if we choose the solution to be cyclic with respect to
$\omega _l^c$
.

sec.title: Open-closed superstring field theory with OCHA structure
sec.p: Now, we are ready to discuss OCHA, the main subject of this paper. In this section, we first see what OCHA is and how it is realized in the superstring field theory, and then give a prescription to construct it explicitly.

sec.title: Interaction with OCHA structure
sec.p: We define classical interactions among the open and closed (type II) superstring mixed system by the vertices described by the following two kinds of surfaces:

list-item.p:
a disk with
$n\ (\ge 0)$
closed superstring punctures on the bulk and
$l+1\ (\ge 1)$
open superstring punctures on the boundary, with n + l ≥ 1.

sec.p:
We can identify the former as the linear maps {
L n
} given in the previous section, which form the cyclic L ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res},\Omega ^\mathrm{c},\lbrace L_n\rbrace )$
. The latter includes both the open superstring interactions ( n = 0) and interactions between open and closed superstrings ( n > 0), and is described by the string products
N n,l
that map n closed superstring fields and l open superstring fields to an open superstring field:
(83)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} &&N_{n,l}\ :\qquad (\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res})^{\wedge n}\otimes (\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res})^{\oplus l} \longrightarrow \mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res},\quad (n,l\ge 0,\, n+l\gt 0),\nonumber \\ &&{\in} \qquad\qquad {\in} &&(\Phi _1 \wedge \cdots \wedge \Phi _n)\otimes (\Psi _1\otimes \cdots \otimes \Psi _l) \quad \longmapsto \quad N_{n,l}(\Phi _1, \ldots , \Phi _n{;}\Psi _1,\ldots ,\Psi _l), \end{eqnarray*} $$
with the identification N
0, l
=
M l
. By definition, the condition
(84)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {P}_{XY}^\mathrm{o}N_{n,l}(\Phi _1,\ldots ,\Phi _n;\Psi _1,\ldots ,\Psi _l) = N_{n,l}(\Phi _1,\ldots ,\Phi _n;\Psi _1,\ldots ,\Psi _l) \end{eqnarray*} $$
holds. The linear maps {
L n
,
N n,l
} satisfying the OCHA relation
(85)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} 0 &=& \sum _{\sigma }\sum _{m=1}^n(-1)^{\epsilon (\sigma )}\frac{1}{m!(n-m)!}N_{n-m+1,l}(L_{m}(\Phi _{\sigma (1)},\ldots , \Phi _{\sigma (m)}),\Phi _{\sigma (m+1)},\ldots ,\Phi _{\sigma (n)};\Psi _1,\ldots ,\Psi _l) \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, \sum _{\sigma }\sum _{m=0}^n\sum _{j=0}^{l}\sum _{i=0}^{l-j}(-1)^{\mu _{m,i}(\sigma )} \frac{1}{m!(n-m)!} N_{m,l-j+1}(\Phi _{\sigma (1)},\ldots ,\Phi _{\sigma (m)}; \nonumber \\ &&\Psi _1,\ldots ,\Psi _i, N_{n-m,j}(\Phi _{\sigma (m+1)},\ldots ,\Phi _{\sigma (n)};\Psi _{i+1},\ldots ,\Psi _{i+j}),\Psi _{i+j+1},\ldots ,\Psi _l), \end{eqnarray*} $$
and the cyclicity condition
(86)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} &&\Omega ^\mathrm{o}(\Psi _1,N_{n,l}(\Phi _1,\ldots ,\Phi _n;\Psi _2,\ldots ,\Psi _{l+1})) \nonumber \\ &&\quad = -(-1)^{\textrm {deg}(\Psi _1)(|\Phi _1|+\cdots +|\Phi _l|+1)} \Omega ^\mathrm{o}(N_{n,l}(\Phi _1,\ldots ,\Phi _n;\Psi _1,\ldots ,\Psi _l),\Psi _{l+1}) \end{eqnarray*} $$
form the cyclic OCHA
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}\oplus \mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o},\Omega ^\mathrm{o},\lbrace L_n,N_{n,l}\rbrace )$
. Here, the sign factor
μ m,i
(σ) in Eq. ( 85 ) is given by
(87)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mu _{m,i}(\sigma ) = \epsilon (\sigma ) + \sum _{j=1}^{m}|\Phi _{\sigma (j)}| + \sum _{j=1}^{i}|\Psi _{j}|(1 + \sum _{k=m+1}^{n}|\Phi _{\sigma (k)}|). \end{eqnarray*} $$
Note that the OCHA relation in Eq. ( 85 ) includes the A ∞ relation in Eq. ( 11 ) as n = 0, at which the cyclicity condition becomes the one for the open superstring in Eq. ( 12 ). In other words, the purely open superstring interactions N
0, l
form the cyclic A ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o},\Omega ^\mathrm{o},\lbrace N_{0,l}\rbrace )$
.

The linear maps in Eq. ( 83 ) are also represented by a degree-odd coderivation
(88)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{N}=\sum _{\substack{n,l=0\\ n+l\ge 1}}^\infty \boldsymbol{N}_{n,l} \end{eqnarray*} $$
acting on
$\mathcal {SH}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res}\otimes \mathcal {TH}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res}$
as
(89)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{N} = \sum _{\substack{n,l=0\\ n+l\gt 0}}\boldsymbol{N}_{n,l} = \sum _{\substack{n,l=0\\ n+l\gt 0}}\sum _{m,j,k=0}^\infty \bigg (\mathbb {I}_m \otimes \Big (\mathbb {I}^{\otimes j}\otimes N_{n,l}\otimes \mathbb {I}^{\otimes k}\Big )\bigg ) \pi _{m+n,j+k+l}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where
π n,l
is the projector onto the subspace
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res})^{\wedge n}\otimes (\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res})^{\otimes l}$
. By extending
$\boldsymbol{L}$
to the coderivation acting on
$\mathcal {SH}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res}\otimes \mathcal {TH}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res}$
as
(90)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{L} = \sum _{n=1}^\infty \ \boldsymbol{L}_n = \sum _{n=1}^\infty \sum _{m,l=0}^\infty \bigg (\Big (L_n\wedge \mathbb {I}_m\Big )\otimes \mathbb {I}^{\otimes l}\bigg )\pi _{n+m,l}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
we can consider the coderivation
$\boldsymbol{L}+\boldsymbol{N}$
. The OCHA relation in Eq. ( 85 ) can then be written as
(91)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{L},\boldsymbol{N}]+\frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{N},\boldsymbol{N}] = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
which we can rewrite as
(92)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{L}+\boldsymbol{N},\boldsymbol{L}+\boldsymbol{N}] = 0 \end{eqnarray*} $$
by combining with the L ∞ relation
$[\boldsymbol{L},\boldsymbol{L}]=0$
. For open-closed superstring field theory, the string interaction
N n,l
must be defined for any combination of four sectors of closed superstring and two sectors of open superstring so that the sum of three kinds (open, left-moving, and right-moving) of picture numbers are conserved:
(93)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{N} = \sum _{\substack{p,n,m,r=0\\ n+m\ge 1 }}^\infty \boldsymbol{N}_{n;m}^{(p)}\big| _{2r}\delta _{p+r,2n+m-1}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where 2 r is the total Ramond number defined by total Ramond number = # of R–NS inputs + # of NS–R inputs + 2(# of R–R inputs) + # of open R inputs − # of open R outputs.

The action with OCHA structure is given by
(94)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} I_\mathrm{oc} = \int ^1_0 dt\, \Omega ^\mathrm{o}\left(\Psi ,\pi _1 \boldsymbol{N}\left(e^{\wedge {\bf \Phi }}\otimes \frac{1}{1-t\Psi }\right)\right), \end{eqnarray*} $$
which describes the open superstring field theory on the closed superstring background.
6
The open superstring field Ψ is dynamical and the closed superstring field Φ is the background field satisfying the equation of motion
(95)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\boldsymbol{L}(e^{\wedge {\bf \Phi }}) = 0. \end{eqnarray*} $$
The arbitrary variation of I oc is given by
(96)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \delta I_\mathrm{oc} = \Omega ^\mathrm{o}\left(\delta \Psi , \pi _1\boldsymbol{N} \left(e^{\wedge {\bf \Phi }}\otimes \frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right)\right). \end{eqnarray*} $$
We can show that the action in Eq. ( 94 ) is invariant under the gauge transformation
(97)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \delta _{\Lambda }\Psi = \pi _1\boldsymbol{N}\left(e^{\wedge {\bf \Phi }}\otimes \left(\frac{1}{1-\Psi }\otimes \Lambda \otimes \frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right)\right) \end{eqnarray*} $$
using the relation in Eq. ( 91 ):
(98)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \delta _{\Lambda }I_\mathrm{oc} &=& \Omega ^\mathrm{o}\left(\Lambda ,\pi _1\boldsymbol{N}\left(e^{\wedge {\bf \Phi }}\otimes \left( \frac{1}{1-\Psi }\otimes \pi _1\boldsymbol{N}\left(e^{\wedge {\bf \Phi }}\otimes \frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right) \otimes \frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right)\right)\right) \nonumber \\ &=&\Omega ^\mathrm{o}\left(\Lambda , \pi _1\boldsymbol{NN}\left(e^{\wedge {\bf \Phi }}\otimes \frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right) \right) \nonumber \\ &=&-\Omega ^\mathrm{o}\left(\Lambda ,\pi _1\boldsymbol{NL}\left(e^{\wedge {\bf \Phi }}\otimes \frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right)\right) \nonumber \\ &=&-\Omega ^\mathrm{o}\left(\Lambda , \pi _1\boldsymbol{N}\left(\left(e^{\wedge {\bf \Phi }}\wedge \pi _1\boldsymbol{L}\left( e^{\wedge {\bf \Phi }}\right)\right)\otimes \frac{1}{1-\Psi } \right)\right) = 0. \end{eqnarray*} $$
The open-closed superstring interaction
$\boldsymbol{N}$
deforms by the background closed superstring field Φ to give a weak A ∞ algebra
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res},\boldsymbol{M}({\bf \Phi }))$
with
(99)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{M}({\bf \Phi }) = \left(\boldsymbol{N}(e^{\bf \Phi }\otimes \mathbb {I})\right)\pi ^\mathrm{o}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Here,
$\mathbb {I}$
is the identity map in
$\mathcal {TH}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res}$
and π o is the projector onto
$\mathcal {TH}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res}$
.

sec.title: Explicit construction of interactions
sec.p:
Let us construct a cyclic OCHA
$(\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}^\mathrm{res}\oplus \mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}^\mathrm{res},\Omega ^\mathrm{c}\oplus \Omega ^\mathrm{o},\boldsymbol{L}+\boldsymbol{N})$
. We assume that the cyclic sub- L ∞ -algebra
$\boldsymbol{L}$
is already constructed in the way given in the previous subsection. Similarly to the previous cases, we can construct
$\boldsymbol{N}$
satisfying the relation in Eq. ( 91 ) and the cyclicity condition in Eq. ( 86 ) in the following two steps. First, consider a degree-odd nilpotent coderivation
(100)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\boldsymbol{\mathcal {O}} = \pi _1\left(\boldsymbol{Q}-\boldsymbol{\eta }+\boldsymbol{A}+\boldsymbol{B}+\boldsymbol{C}\right) -\left(1-\frac{1}{2}(X+\bar{X})\right)\pi _1^{(1,1)}\boldsymbol{B} \end{eqnarray*} $$
satisfying
$[\boldsymbol{\mathcal {O}},\boldsymbol{\mathcal {O}}]=0$
, or equivalently two mutually commutative coderivations
(101)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\boldsymbol{\mathcal {D}} = \pi _1\boldsymbol{Q}+\pi _1^{(0,0)}\boldsymbol{B}+\pi _1^0(\boldsymbol{A}+\boldsymbol{C}), \end{eqnarray*} $$
(102)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}} = \pi _1\boldsymbol{\eta }-\left(\pi _1^{(1,0)}+\pi _1^{(0,1)}+ \frac{1}{2}(X+\bar{X})\pi _1^{(1,1)}\right)\boldsymbol{B}-\pi _1^1(\boldsymbol{A}+\boldsymbol{C}), \end{eqnarray*} $$
satisfying
$[\boldsymbol{\mathcal {D}},\boldsymbol{\mathcal {D}}]=[\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}},\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}}] =[\boldsymbol{\mathcal {D}},\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}}]=0$
, where
$\boldsymbol{Q}$
acts as
$\boldsymbol{Q}_\mathrm{c}$
or
$\boldsymbol{Q}_\mathrm{o}$
on
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}$
or
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}$
, respectively, and similarly
$\boldsymbol{\eta }$
acts as
$\boldsymbol{\eta }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }}$
or
$\boldsymbol{\eta }$
on
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}$
or
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}$
, respectively. The degree-odd coderivations
$\boldsymbol{A}$
and
$\boldsymbol{B}$
are those for constructing the A ∞ and L ∞ algebras in Eqs. ( 21 ) and ( 65 ), and
$\boldsymbol{C}$
is the one for constructing the open-closed interaction defined by respecting the cyclic Ramond number:
(103)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{C} = \sum _{p,n,l,r=0}^\infty \delta _{p+r,2n+l+1} \boldsymbol{C}_{n+1,l}^{(p)}\big| ^{2r}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
The OCHA relations can be written as the L ∞ relations in Eq. (68) and the relations
(104a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{C}] + [\boldsymbol{A},\boldsymbol{C}]^1 + \frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{C},\boldsymbol{C}]^1 + [\boldsymbol{B},\boldsymbol{C}]^{11} = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(104b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{C}] - [\boldsymbol{A},\boldsymbol{C}]^2 - \frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{C},\boldsymbol{C}]^2 - [\boldsymbol{B},\boldsymbol{C}]^{21} - [\boldsymbol{B},\boldsymbol{C}]^{12} - [\boldsymbol{B},\boldsymbol{C}]^{22}_{X+\bar{X}} = 0. \end{eqnarray*} $$
If we find such
$\boldsymbol{A}$
,
$\boldsymbol{B}$
, and
$\boldsymbol{C}$
, the cohomomorphism
(105)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\hat{\boldsymbol{F}}^{-1} = \pi _1\mathbb {I}- \left(\Xi ^\mathrm{c}\pi _1^{(1,0)} + \bar{\Xi }^\mathrm{c}\pi _1^{(0,1)} +\frac{1}{2}(\bar{\Xi }^\mathrm{c}X^\mathrm{c}+\Xi ^\mathrm{c}\bar{X}^\mathrm{c})\pi _1^{(1,1)} \right)\boldsymbol{B} - \Xi ^\mathrm{o}\pi _1^1(\boldsymbol{A}+\boldsymbol{C}) \end{eqnarray*} $$
transforms
$\boldsymbol{\mathcal {D}}$
and
$\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}}$
to the ones we eventually construct as
(106)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\hat{\boldsymbol{F}}^{-1}\boldsymbol{\mathcal {D}}\hat{\boldsymbol{F}} = \pi _1\boldsymbol{Q} + \mathcal {G}^\mathrm{c}\pi _1\boldsymbol{B}\hat{\boldsymbol{F}}\ + \mathcal {G}^0\pi _1(\boldsymbol{A}+\boldsymbol{C})\hat{\boldsymbol{F}} = \pi _1(\boldsymbol{L}+\boldsymbol{N}), \end{eqnarray*} $$
(107)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\hat{\boldsymbol{F}}^{-1}\boldsymbol{\mathcal {C}}\hat{\boldsymbol{F}} = \boldsymbol{\eta }. \end{eqnarray*} $$

We can construct
$\boldsymbol{C}$
similarly to
$\boldsymbol{A}$
and
$\boldsymbol{B}$
, which we already found. By introducing parameters s and t , we consider the generating functions in Eq. ( 26 ), and Eq. ( 72 ), and
(108)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{C}(s,t) = \sum _{p,m,n,l,r=0}^\infty \delta _{m+p+r,2n+l+1}\, s^{m} t^{p} \boldsymbol{C}_{n+1,l}^{(p)}\big| ^{2r}\ \equiv \ \sum _{p=0}^\infty t^p \boldsymbol{C}^{(p)}(s), \end{eqnarray*} $$
and extend the relations in Eqs. (104) to
(109a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{I}(s,t) &\equiv& [\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{C}(s,t)] + [\boldsymbol{A}(s,t),\boldsymbol{C}(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} + \frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{C}(s,t),\boldsymbol{C}(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, [\boldsymbol{B}(s,s,t),\boldsymbol{C}(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1(s,s,t)} = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(109b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{J}(s,t) &\equiv& [\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{C}(s,t)] - [\boldsymbol{A}(s,t),\boldsymbol{C}(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_2(t)} - \frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{C}(s,t),\boldsymbol{C}(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_2(t)} \nonumber \\ &&-\,\, [\boldsymbol{B}(s,s,t),\boldsymbol{C}(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_2(s)+\bar{\mathfrak {c}}_2(s)} = 0. \end{eqnarray*} $$
We can show that if
$\boldsymbol{C}(s,t)$
satisfies
(110a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _t\boldsymbol{C}(s,t) &=& [\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{\nu }(s,t)] \nonumber \\ &&+ \,\,[\boldsymbol{A}(s,t),\boldsymbol{\nu }(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} + [\boldsymbol{C}(s,t),\boldsymbol{\mu }(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} + [\boldsymbol{C}(s,t),\boldsymbol{\nu }(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} \nonumber \\ &&+ \,\,[\boldsymbol{B}(s,s,t),\boldsymbol{\nu }(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1(s,s,t)} + [\boldsymbol{C}(s,t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,s,t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1(s,s,t)} \nonumber \\ &&+ \,\,[\boldsymbol{B}(s,s,t),\boldsymbol{C}(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {d}(s,s)}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(110b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _s\boldsymbol{C}(s,t) &=& [\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{\nu }(s,t)] \nonumber \\ &&-\,\, [\boldsymbol{A}(s,t),\boldsymbol{\nu }(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_2(t)} - [\boldsymbol{C}(s,t),\boldsymbol{\mu }(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_2(t)} - [\boldsymbol{C}(s,t),\boldsymbol{\nu }(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {o}_2(t)} \nonumber \\ &&-\,\, [\boldsymbol{B}(s,s,t),\boldsymbol{\nu }(s,t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_2(t)+\bar{\mathfrak {c}}_2(t)} - [\boldsymbol{C}(s,t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,s,t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_2(t)+\bar{\mathfrak {c}}_2(t)} \end{eqnarray*} $$
with the degree-even coderivation
(111)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{\nu }(s,t) = \sum _{p,n,l,r,m=0}^\infty \delta _{p+m+r,2n+l}\, s^m t^p \boldsymbol{\nu }_{n+1,l}^{(p+1)}\big| ^{2r}\ \equiv \ \sum _{p=0}^\infty t^p \boldsymbol{\nu }^{(p+1)}(s), \end{eqnarray*} $$
then the t derivative of the left-hand sides of Eq. (109) become
(112a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _t\boldsymbol{I}(s,t) &=& [\boldsymbol{I}(s,t),(\boldsymbol{\mu }(s,t)+\boldsymbol{\nu }(s,t))]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} + [\boldsymbol{I}(s,t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,s,t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1(s,s,t)} \nonumber \\ &&+ \,\,[\boldsymbol{I}(s,t), \boldsymbol{B}(s,s,t)]_{\mathfrak {d}(s,s)}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(112b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _t\boldsymbol{J}(s,t) &=& [\boldsymbol{J}(s,t),(\boldsymbol{\mu }(s,t)+\boldsymbol{\nu }(s,t))]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} + [\boldsymbol{J}(s,t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,s,t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1(s,s,t)} \nonumber \\ &&+ \,\,[\boldsymbol{J}(s,t),\boldsymbol{B}(s,\bar{s},t)]_{\mathfrak {d}(s,s)} - \partial _s\boldsymbol{I}(s,t) - [\boldsymbol{I}(s,t),(\boldsymbol{\mu }(s,t)+\boldsymbol{\nu }(s,t))]_{\mathfrak {o}_2(t)} \end{eqnarray*} $$
by using the differential equations in Eq. (29) and
(113)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _t\boldsymbol{B}(s,s,t) &=& [\boldsymbol{Q},(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,s,t)] \nonumber \\ &&+ \,\,[\boldsymbol{B}(s,s,t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,s,t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1(s,s,t)} +\frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{B}(s,s,t),\boldsymbol{B}(s,s,t)]_{\mathfrak {d}(s,s)} , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(114)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _s\boldsymbol{B}(s,s,t) = [\boldsymbol{\eta }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }},(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,s,t)] - [\boldsymbol{B}(s,s,t),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})(s,s,t)]_{\mathfrak {c}_2(t)+\bar{\mathfrak {c}}_2(t)}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
satisfied by
$\boldsymbol{A}(s,t)$
and
$\boldsymbol{B}(s,s,t)$
, respectively. Therefore, if the relations at t = 0,
(115a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{I}(s,0) &=& [\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{C}(s,0)] + [\boldsymbol{A}(s,0),\boldsymbol{C}(s,0)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} + \frac{1}{2}[\boldsymbol{C}(s,0),\boldsymbol{C}(s,0)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} \nonumber \\ &&+ \,\,[\boldsymbol{B}(s,s,0),\boldsymbol{C}(s,0)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1(s,s,0)} = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(115b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{J}(s,0) &=& [\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{C}(s,0)] = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
hold, then
$\boldsymbol{I}(s,t)=\boldsymbol{J}(s,t)=0$
for any t . We can easily find that the coderivation
$\boldsymbol{C}(s,0)$
satisfying Eq. (115) has no picture number and is given by setting
(116)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{C}(s,0) = \boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s) = \boldsymbol{N}_\mathrm{B}(s) , \end{eqnarray*} $$
with
(117)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{N}_\mathrm{B}(s) = \sum _{m,n,l,r=0}^\infty s^{m}\delta _{m+r,2n+l+1}(\boldsymbol{N}_\mathrm{B})_{n+1,l}\big| ^{2r}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
which can constructed similarly to those of the bosonic open-closed string field theory [ 7 ]. Therefore, we can obtain
$\boldsymbol{C}(s,t)$
satisfying Eq. (109) by recursively solving the differential equations in Eq. (110) under the initial condition in Eq. ( 116 ) to be cyclic with respect to
$\omega _l^o$
. In Appendix A , we give a concrete procedure to solve them for some lower orders. The cyclic OCHA
$(\mathcal {H}^\mathrm{res},\Omega ,\boldsymbol{L}+\boldsymbol{N})$
is eventually constructed by transforming using the cohomomorphism in Eq. ( 105 ).

sec.title: Mapping to a WZW-like action
sec.p: The WZW-like formulation is a complementary way to construct superstring field theories using the large Hilbert space [ 18–20 , 26–31 ]. We can map the action we constructed in the previous section to the WZW-like action as in the open, heterotic, and type II superstring field theories [ 18–20 , 27 ].

Let us first focus on the NS ⊕ NS–NS sector, which we simply call the NS sector in this section. The map between the two (homotopy-based and WZW-like) formulations is given by the cohomomorphism
$\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}=\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{c}\otimes \hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{o}$
[ 14 , 18 , 20 ] with
(118)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{c} = \vec{\mathcal {P}}\exp \left( \int ^1_0dt\, (\boldsymbol{\lambda }+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})^\mathrm{NS}(0,t)\right),\qquad \hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{o} = \vec{\mathcal {P}}\exp \left( \int ^1_0dt\, \boldsymbol{\mu }^\mathrm{NS}(0,t)\right), \end{eqnarray*} $$
where
(119)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} (\boldsymbol{\lambda }+ \bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }})^\mathrm{NS}(s,t) = \sum _{m,p=0}^\infty \sum _{\bar{m},\bar{p}=0}^\infty s^{m+\bar{m}}t^{p+\bar{p}} \left( \boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(p+1,\bar{p})}_{m+p+2,\bar{m}+\bar{p}+1}\big| ^{(0,0)} + \bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(p,\bar{p}+1)}_{m+p+1,\bar{m}+\bar{p}+2}\big| ^{(0,0)}\right), \end{eqnarray*} $$
(120)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{\mu }^\mathrm{NS}(s,t) = \sum _{m,p=0}^\infty s^m t^p \boldsymbol{\mu }_{m+p+2}^{(p+1)}\big| ^{0}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
This cohomomorphism maps the string fields (Φ NS–NS , Ψ NS ) to those in the WZW-like formulation ( V o , V c ) as
(121)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1^\mathrm{c}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{c}(e^{\wedge \Phi _{\mathrm{NS}\!-\!\mathrm{NS}}}) = G_\mathrm{c}(V_\mathrm{c}),\qquad \pi _1^\mathrm{o}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{o}\left(\frac{1}{1-\Psi _\mathrm{NS}}\right) = G_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o}), \end{eqnarray*} $$
where
(122)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} G_\mathrm{c}(V) = \eta \bar{\eta } V + \frac{1}{2}\left( L^\eta _2(\eta \bar{\eta } V,\bar{\eta }V)+\eta L_2^{\bar{\eta }}(\eta \bar{\eta }V,V) \right) + \cdots , \end{eqnarray*} $$
are the pure-gauge string fields of the type II superstring identically satisfying
(123)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{c}^\eta (e^{\wedge G_\mathrm{c}(V_\mathrm{c})}) = 0,\qquad \boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{c}^{\bar{\eta }}(e^{\wedge G_\mathrm{c}(V_\mathrm{c})}) = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
with
$(\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{c}^\eta ,\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{c}^{\bar{\eta }})=(\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{c}\boldsymbol{\eta }_\mathrm{c}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{c}^{-1}, \hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{c}\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }}_\mathrm{c}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{c}^{-1})$
[ 30 ]. The pure-gauge string field G o ( V o ) of the open superstring is similarly defined by a composite string field of V o identically satisfying the equation
(124)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{o}^\eta \left(\frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o})}\right) = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
with
$\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{o}^\eta =\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{\eta }_\mathrm{o}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{o}^{-1}$
. We give a prescription to obtain the explicit form of G o ( V o ) in Appendix B . The (dynamical) equation of motion of the open superstring is mapped as
(125)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\tilde{\boldsymbol{N}}_\mathrm{NS}\left(e^{\wedge G_\mathrm{c}(V_\mathrm{c})}\otimes \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o})}\right) = 0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
with
(126)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \tilde{\boldsymbol{N}}_\mathrm{NS} = \hat{\boldsymbol{g}}\boldsymbol{N}_\mathrm{NS}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}^{-1} = \boldsymbol{Q}_\mathrm{o}+\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}(\boldsymbol{N}_\mathrm{NS}-\boldsymbol{M}_\mathrm{NS})\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}^{-1}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where V c is a background field satisfying the equation of motion of the closed superstring Q c G c ( V c ) = 0. In order to give the WZW-like action deriving this equation of motion in Eq. (124), we define the associated string field as
(127)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} B_d(V_\mathrm{o}) = \pi _1^\mathrm{o}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{\xi _d}\left(\frac{1}{1-\Psi _\mathrm{NS}}\right), \end{eqnarray*} $$
where d = t, δ , or Q , and
$\boldsymbol{\xi _d}$
is the coderivation derived from
ξ∂ t
, ξδ , or
$-\xi \pi _1\boldsymbol{M}_\mathrm{NS}$
, respectively. We can show that the relations
(128)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} &\ dG_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o}) = (-1)^d D_\eta B_d(V_\mathrm{o}), \end{eqnarray*} $$
(129)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} &\ D_\eta \left(\partial _tB_\delta (V_\mathrm{o})-\delta B_{\partial _t}(V_\mathrm{o})\right) = 0 \end{eqnarray*} $$
hold,
7
where D η is the nilpotent linear operator defined by
(130)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} D_\eta \varphi &=& \pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{o}^\eta \left(\frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes \varphi \otimes \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o})}\right) \nonumber \\ &=&\pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{L}^\eta \left(e^{\wedge G_\mathrm{c}(V_\mathrm{c})}\otimes \left( \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes \varphi \otimes \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o})}\right)\right), \end{eqnarray*} $$
acting on an open superstring field
$\varphi \in \mathcal {H}_\mathrm{NS}$
. The coderivation
$\boldsymbol{L}^{\eta }$
acts as
$\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{c}^{\eta }+\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{c}^{\bar{\eta }}$
on
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{c}$
and as
$\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{o}^{\eta }$
on
$\mathcal {H}_\mathrm{o}$
. Then, the WZW-like action for the NS sector is given by
(131)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} I_\mathrm{WZW}^\mathrm{NS} = \int _0^1 dt\, \omega _\mathrm{l}^\mathrm{o}\left(B_{t}(t V_\mathrm{o}), \pi _1\tilde{\boldsymbol{N}}_\mathrm{NS}\bigg (e^{\wedge G_\mathrm{c}(V_\mathrm{c})}\otimes \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(t V_\mathrm{o})}\bigg ) \right), \end{eqnarray*} $$
which is invariant under the gauge transformation
(132)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} B_\delta (V_\mathrm{o}) = \pi _1\tilde{\boldsymbol{N}}_\mathrm{NS}\left(e^{\wedge G_\mathrm{c}(V_\mathrm{c})}\otimes \left( \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes \Lambda \otimes \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o})}\right)\right) + D_\eta \Omega . \end{eqnarray*} $$

It is straightforward to extend these results from the NS sector to all the sectors. Since
$\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{c}$
and
$\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{o}$
act as the identity operators outside the NS sector, we find that
(133)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1^\mathrm{c}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{c}\left(e^{\wedge \Phi }\right) = \pi _1^\mathrm{c}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{c}\left(e^{\wedge \Phi _{\mathrm{NS}\!-\!\mathrm{NS}}}\right) + \Phi _{\mathrm{R}\!-\!\mathrm{NS}} + \Phi _{\mathrm{NS}\!-\!\mathrm{R}} + \Phi _{\mathrm{R}\!-\!\mathrm{R}}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(134)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1^\mathrm{o}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{o}\left(\frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right) = \pi _1^\mathrm{o}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_\mathrm{o}\left(\frac{1}{1-\Psi _\mathrm{NS}}\right) + \Psi _\mathrm{R}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
and can identify the components (Φ R–NS , Φ NS–R , Φ R–R ; Ψ R ) with those in the WZW-like formulation
$(\Psi _\mathrm{c}, \bar{\Psi }_\mathrm{c},\Sigma _\mathrm{c};\Psi _\mathrm{o})$
:
(135)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Phi _{\mathrm{R}\!-\!\mathrm{NS}} = \Psi _\mathrm{c},\qquad \Phi _{\mathrm{NS}\!-\!\mathrm{R}} = \bar{\Psi }_\mathrm{c},\qquad \Phi _{\mathrm{R}\!-\!\mathrm{R}} = \Sigma _\mathrm{c},\qquad \Psi _\mathrm{R} = \Psi _\mathrm{o}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Thus, these components are also annihilated by η c and
$\bar{\eta }_\mathrm{c}$
(or
η o
) and satisfy the constraint in Eq. ( 39 ) (or Eq. ( 1 )). The WZW-like action of the open superstring field theory on the general closed string backgrounds is eventually written as
(136)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} I_\mathrm{WZW} = \int ^1_0 dt\, \omega _\mathrm{l}^\mathrm{o}\bigg (\mathcal {B}_{t}(\mathcal {V}_\mathrm{o}(t)), (\mathcal {G}^\mathrm{o})^{-1}\pi _1\tilde{\boldsymbol{N}}\bigg (e^{\wedge (G(V_\mathrm{c})+\Psi _\mathrm{c}+\bar{\Psi }_\mathrm{c}+\Sigma _\mathrm{c})}\otimes \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o}(t))-\Psi _\mathrm{o}(t)}\bigg )\bigg ), \nonumber\\ \end{eqnarray*} $$
where
$\tilde{\boldsymbol{N}}=\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}\boldsymbol{N}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}^{-1}$
and
(137)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {B}_{t}(\mathcal {V}_\mathrm{o}(t)) = B_{t}(V_\mathrm{o}(t))+\xi _0\partial _t\Psi _\mathrm{o}(t). \end{eqnarray*} $$
The closed superstring backgrounds
$(V_\mathrm{c},\Psi _\mathrm{c},\bar{\Psi }_\mathrm{c},\Sigma _\mathrm{c})$
satisfy
(138)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pi _1\tilde{\boldsymbol{L}}\left(e^{\wedge (G_\mathrm{c}(V_\mathrm{c})+\Psi _\mathrm{c}+\bar{\Psi }_\mathrm{c}+\Sigma _\mathrm{c})}\right) = 0 \end{eqnarray*} $$
with
$\tilde{\boldsymbol{L}}=\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}\boldsymbol{L}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}^{-1}$
. Note that, since
$\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}$
acts as the identity except on the NS sector,
$\tilde{\boldsymbol{N}}$
and
$\tilde{\boldsymbol{L}}$
preserve the constraints in Eqs. ( 1 ) and ( 39 ), respectively. The WZW-like action in Eq. ( 136 ) is invariant under the gauge transformation
(139)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {B}_\delta (\mathcal {V}_\mathrm{o}) = \pi _1\tilde{\boldsymbol{N}} \left(e^{\wedge (G_\mathrm{c}(V_\mathrm{c})+\Psi _\mathrm{c}+\bar{\Psi }_\mathrm{c}+\Sigma _\mathrm{c})}\otimes \left( \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o})-\Psi _\mathrm{o}}\otimes (\Lambda +\xi \lambda )\otimes \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o})-\Psi _\mathrm{o}}\right)\right), \nonumber\\ \end{eqnarray*} $$
which is also obtained through the map
$\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}$
. Here, Λ and λ are the gauge parameters in the NS and R sectors, respectively; λ is annihilated by η and satisfies the constraint in Eq. ( 1 ).

sec.title: Summary and discussion
sec.p: We have constructed interactions for the open-closed superstring field theory based on the OCHA structure, which provides the open-closed superstring field theory on general closed superstring backgrounds. We also gave a corresponding WZW-like action for open-closed superstring field theory through a field redefinition.

Recently, the open string field theory deformed with a gauge-invariant open-closed coupling has been studied [ 24 , 32–35 ]. The effective open superstring field theory is governed by a weak A ∞ structure which includes a non-trivial tadpole term, destabilizing the initial perturbative vacuum. It requires shifting the vacuum to a new equilibrium point. The open-closed superstring field theory given in this paper provides a basis for such an analysis on more general closed-superstring backgrounds described by classical solutions of the nonlinear equation of motion of the closed superstring field theory.
