app.title: Appendix A. Explicit procedure for solving Eqs. (76) and (110)
app.p:
Similar to the open superstring case in Sect. 2 , the differential equations in Eq. (76) for constructing an L ∞ algebra can be solved recursively with the initial condition in Eq. ( 82 ). The concrete procedure is complicated, however, because the parameter t counts only the total picture number without independently counting the left- and right-moving picture numbers. We first rewrite the differential equations in Eq. (76) in the form
(A1)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} &&\sum _{q=0}^{p+1}(p+1)\boldsymbol{B}^{(p-q+1,q)}(s,\bar{s})\ \nonumber \\ &&\quad=\sum _{q=0}^p[\boldsymbol{Q},(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(p-q+1,q)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(p-q,q+1)})(s,\bar{s})] \nonumber \\ &&\qquad+\,\, \sum _{q=0}^p\sum _{l=0}^q\sum _{m=0}^l [\boldsymbol{B}^{(p-q,q-l)}(s,\bar{s}),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(l-m+1,m)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(l-m,m+1)})(s,\bar{s})]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,\bar{s})} \nonumber \\ &&\qquad+\,\, \sum _{q=0}^{p-1}\sum _{l=0}^q\sum _{m=0}^l [\boldsymbol{B}^{(p-q-1,q-l)}(s,\bar{s}),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(l-m+1,m)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(l-m,m+1)})(s,\bar{s})]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^1(s,\bar{s})} \nonumber \\ &&\qquad+\,\, \frac{1}{2}\sum _{q=0}^p\sum _{l=0}^q\sum _{m=0}^l [\boldsymbol{B}^{(p-q,q-l)}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{B}^{(l-m,m)}(s,\bar{s})]_{\mathfrak {d}(s,\bar{s})}\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(A2)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} &&\sum _{q=0}^p[\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(p-q+1,q)}(s,\bar{s})] \nonumber \\ &&\quad= \sum _{q=0}^p\partial _s\boldsymbol{B}^{(p-q,q)}(s,\bar{s})\ \nonumber \\ &&\qquad-\,\, \sum _{q=0}^{p-1}\sum _{l=0}^q\sum _{m=0}^l [\boldsymbol{B}^{(p-q-1,q-l)}(s,\bar{s}),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(l-m+1,m)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(l-m,m+1)})(s,\bar{s})]^{21} \nonumber \\ &&\qquad-\,\, \sum _{q=0}^{p-2}\sum _{l=0}^k\sum _{m=0}^l [\boldsymbol{B}^{(p-q-2,q-l)}(s,\bar{s}),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(l-m+1,m)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(l-m,m+1)})(s,\bar{s})]^{22}_{\bar{X}}\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(A3)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} &&\sum _{q=0}^p[\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }},\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(p-q,q+1)}(s,\bar{s})] \nonumber \\ &&\quad= \sum _{q=0}^p\partial _{\bar{s}}\boldsymbol{B}^{(p-q,q)}(s,\bar{s})\ \nonumber \\ &&\qquad-\,\, \sum _{q=0}^{p-1}\sum _{l=0}^q\sum _{m=0}^l [\boldsymbol{B}^{(p-q-1,q-l)}(s,\bar{s}),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(l-m+1,m)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(l-m,m+1)})(s,\bar{s})]^{12} \nonumber \\ &&\qquad-\,\, \sum _{q=0}^{p-2}\sum _{l=0}^q\sum _{m=0}^l [\boldsymbol{B}^{(p-q-2,q-l)}(s,\bar{s}),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(l-m+1,m)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(l-m,m+1)})(s,\bar{s})]^{22}_{X}\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
where we expanded
$\mathfrak {c}_1(s,\bar{s},t)$
in powers of t as
$\mathfrak {c}_1(s,\bar{s},t)=\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,\bar{s})+t\mathfrak {c}_1^1(s,\bar{s})$
with
$\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,\bar{s})=\pi ^{(0,0)}+s\pi ^{(1,0)}+ \bar{s}\pi ^{(0,1)}+s\bar{s}\pi ^{(1,1)}$
and
$\mathfrak {c}_1^1(s,\bar{s})=(s\bar{X}+\bar{s}X)\pi ^{(1,1)}$
. Equation ( A1 ) determines several
$\boldsymbol{B}^{(p,\bar{p})}(s,\bar{s})$
with the same total picture number simultaneously. We must split them by each left- and right-moving picture number. The explicit decomposition for the NS–NS sector was given in Ref. [ 16 ], but we have not yet extended it to the whole sectors in a closed form. Instead, we give an explicit decomposition for some lower picture numbers and show how the equations determine
$\boldsymbol{B}^{(p,\bar{p})}(s,\bar{s})$
for all the higher picture numbers. First, setting p = 0 in Eqs. ( A2 ) and ( A3 ), we have
(A4)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})] = \partial _s\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s})\, ,\qquad [\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }},\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})] = \partial _{\bar{s}}\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s})\, . \end{eqnarray*} $$
We can solve them as
(A5)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s}) = \xi _0\circ \partial _s\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s})\, ,\qquad \bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s}) = \bar{\xi }_0\circ \partial _{\bar{s}}\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s}) \end{eqnarray*} $$
under the initial conditions
$\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s})=\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s})$
. The operations
$\xi _0^\mathrm{c}\,\circ$
and
$\bar{\xi }_0^\mathrm{c}\,\circ$
are defined on general coderivation
$\boldsymbol{B}=\sum _{n=0}^\infty \boldsymbol{B}_{n+2}$
by
(A6a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \xi _0^\mathrm{c}\circ \boldsymbol{B} = \sum _{n,k=0}^\infty \Big ( (\xi _0^\mathrm{c}\circ B_{n+2})\wedge \mathbb {I}_k\Big )\pi ^\mathrm{c}_{n+k+2} , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(A6b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \xi _0^\mathrm{c}\circ B_{n+2} = \frac{1}{n+3}\Big ( \xi _0^\mathrm{c} B_{n+2}-(-1)^{\textrm {deg}(B)}B_{n+2}(\xi _0^\mathrm{c}\wedge \mathbb {I}_{n+1}) \Big ) , \end{eqnarray*} $$
and those replacing
$\xi _0^\mathrm{c}$
with
$\bar{\xi }_0^\mathrm{c}$
. Equation ( A1 ) at p = 0 splits into two equations:
(A7)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{B}^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})&=&[\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})] + [\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,\bar{s})} +\frac{\bar{s}}{2}[ \boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s})]^{22}_{\Xi } , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(A8)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{B}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})&=&[\boldsymbol{Q},\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})] + [\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s}),\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,\bar{s})} +\frac{s}{2}[ \boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s})]^{22}_{\bar{\Xi }} . \end{eqnarray*} $$
Substituting Eq. ( A5 ) into these expressions, we obtain
$\boldsymbol{B}^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})$
and
$\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})$
independently. Next, setting p = 1 in Eqs. ( A2 ) and ( A3 ), we have
(A9)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(2,0)}(s,\bar{s})] = \partial _s\boldsymbol{B}^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})+ [\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})]^{21}\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(A10)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,1)}(s,\bar{s})] = \partial _s\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})+ [\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s}),\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})]^{21}\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(A11)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }},\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(1,1)}(s,\bar{s})] = \partial _{\bar{s}}\boldsymbol{B}^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})+ [\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})]^{12}\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(A12)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\bar{\boldsymbol{\eta }},\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,2)}(s,\bar{s})] = \partial _{\bar{s}}\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})+ [\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s}),\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})]^{12}\, . \end{eqnarray*} $$
Since all the quantities on the right-hand sides are already known, we can solve these equations for
$\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(2,0)}(s,\bar{s})$
,
$\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,1)}(s,\bar{s})$
,
$\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(1,1)}(s,\bar{s})$
, and
$\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,2)}(s,\bar{s})$
by acting
$\xi _0^\mathrm{c}\,\circ$
or
$\bar{\xi }_0^\mathrm{c}\,\circ$
as
(A13)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(2,0)}(s,\bar{s}) = \xi _0^\mathrm{c}\circ \Big ( \partial _s\boldsymbol{B}^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})+ [\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})]^{21} \Big )\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(A14)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,1)}(s,\bar{s}) = \xi _0^\mathrm{c}\circ \Big ( \partial _s\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})+ [\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})]^{21} \Big )\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(A15)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(1,1)}(s,\bar{s}) = \bar{\xi }_0^\mathrm{c}\circ \Big ( \partial _{\bar{s}}\boldsymbol{B}^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})+ [\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})]^{12} \Big )\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(A16)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,2)}(s,\bar{s}) = \bar{\xi }_0^\mathrm{c}\circ \Big ( \partial _{\bar{s}}\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})+ [\boldsymbol{L}_\mathrm{B}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})]^{12} \Big )\, . \end{eqnarray*} $$

At p = 1, Eq. ( A1 ) can be split as
(A17a)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} 2\boldsymbol{B}^{(2,0)}(s,\bar{s}) &=& [\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(2,0)}(s,\bar{s})] +[\boldsymbol{B}^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,\bar{s})} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\,[\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(2,0)}(s,\bar{s})]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,\bar{s})} +\bar{s} [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})]^{22}_{X} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\,\bar{s} [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{B}^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})]^{22}_{\Xi }\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(A17b)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} 2\boldsymbol{B}^{(1,1)}(s,\bar{s}) &=& [\boldsymbol{Q},(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,1)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(1,1)})(s,\bar{s})] +[\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s}),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,1)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(1,1)})(s,\bar{s})]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,\bar{s})} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\,[\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,\bar{s})} +[\boldsymbol{B}^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s}),\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,\bar{s})} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\,s [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})]^{22}_{\bar{X}} + \bar{s} [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s}),\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})]^{22}_{X} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\,s [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{B}^{(1,0)}(s,\bar{s})]^{22}_{\bar{\Xi }} + \bar{s} [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})]^{22}_{\Xi }\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
(A17c)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} 2\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,2)}(s,\bar{s}) &=& [\boldsymbol{Q},\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,2)}(s,\bar{s})] +[\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s}),\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,\bar{s})} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\,[\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s}),\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,2)}(s,\bar{s})]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,\bar{s})} + s [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s}),\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})]^{22}_{\bar{X}} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, s [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,\bar{s}),\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,1)}(s,\bar{s})]^{22}_{\bar{\Xi }}\, . \end{eqnarray*} $$
All the quantities on the right-hand sides have been obtained in the previous steps, and thus Eqs. (A17) determine
$\boldsymbol{B}^{(2,0)}(s,\bar{s})$
,
$\boldsymbol{B}^{(2,0)}(s,\bar{s})$
, and
$\boldsymbol{B}^{(2,0)}(s,\bar{s})$
. Repeating the procedure, we can obtain
$\boldsymbol{B}^{(p,\bar{p})}(s,\bar{s})$
for arbitrary p and
$\bar{p}$
independently. A similar but slightly different analysis was give in Ref. [ 20 ].

We start from Eq. ( A19 ) at p = 0 with the initial condition in Eq. ( 116 ):
(A20)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(1)}(s)] = \partial _s\boldsymbol{N}_\mathrm{B}(s) . \end{eqnarray*} $$
This is solved as
(A21)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{\nu }^{(1)}(s) = \xi _0^\mathrm{o}\circ \partial _s\boldsymbol{N}_\mathrm{B}(s) \end{eqnarray*} $$
so as to respect the cyclicity, where
$\xi _0^\mathrm{o}\,\circ$
is defined on the general coderivation
$\boldsymbol{C}=\sum _{n,l=0}^\infty \boldsymbol{C}_{n+1,l}$
by
(A22)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \xi _0^\mathrm{o}\circ \boldsymbol{C} = \sum _{n,l=0}^\infty \sum _{m,j,k=0}^\infty \bigg (\mathbb {I}_m \otimes \Big (\mathbb {I}^{\otimes j}\otimes \xi _0^\mathrm{o}\circ C_{n+1,l}\otimes \mathbb {I}^{\otimes k}\Big )\bigg ) \pi _{m+n+1,j+k+l}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(A23)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \xi _0^\mathrm{o}\circ C_{n+1,l} = \frac{1}{l+1}\Bigg ( \xi _0^\mathrm{o} C_{n+1,l}-(-1)^{\textrm {deg}(C)}\sum _{m=0}^{l-1}C_{n+1,l}\Big (\mathbb {I}_{n+1}\otimes \big (\mathbb {I}^{\otimes (l-m-1)}\otimes \xi _0^\mathrm{o}\otimes \mathbb {I}^{\otimes m}\big )\Big ) \Bigg ) . \nonumber\\ \end{eqnarray*} $$
Then, Eq. ( A18 ) at p = 0 ,
(A24)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{C}^{(1)}(s) &=& [\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(1)}(s)] \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, [\left(\boldsymbol{A}^{(0)}(s)+\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s)\right),\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(1)}(s)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} + [\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s),\boldsymbol{\mu }^{(1)}(s)]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,s),\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(1)}(s)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,s)} + [\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)})(s,s)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,s)} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, s [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,s),\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s)]^{22}_{\Xi +\bar{\Xi }}\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
determines
$\boldsymbol{C}^{(1)}(s)$
. Next, we solve Eq. ( A19 ) at p = 1 ,
(A25)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {[}\boldsymbol{\eta },\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(2)}(s)] &=& \partial _s\boldsymbol{C}^{(1)}(s) \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, [\left(\boldsymbol{A}^{(0)}(s)+\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s)\right),\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(1)}]^2 + [\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s),\boldsymbol{\mu }^{(1)}]^2 \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,s),\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(1)}(s)]^{21+12} + [\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)})(s,s)]^{21+12}\, , \end{eqnarray*} $$
as
(A26)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \boldsymbol{\nu }^{(2)}(s) &=& \xi _0^\mathrm{o}\circ \Big (\partial _s\boldsymbol{C}^{(1)}(s) + [\left(\boldsymbol{A}^{(0)}(s)+\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s)\right),\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(1)}]^2 + [\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s),\boldsymbol{\mu }^{(1)}]^2 \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,s),\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(1)}(s)]^{21+12} + [\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)})(s,s)]^{21+12} \Big )\, . \end{eqnarray*} $$
Equation ( A18 ) at p = 1 determines
$\boldsymbol{C}^{(2)}(s)$
as
(A27)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} 2\boldsymbol{C}^{(2)}(s) &=& [\boldsymbol{Q},\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(2)}(s)] \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, [\left(\boldsymbol{A}^{(1)}(s)+\boldsymbol{C}^{(1)}(s)\right),\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(1)}]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} + [\boldsymbol{C}^{(1)}(s),\boldsymbol{\mu }^{(1)}]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, [\left(\boldsymbol{A}^{(0)}(s)+\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s)\right),\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(2)}]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} + [\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s),\boldsymbol{\mu }^{(2)}]_{\mathfrak {o}_1(s)} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, [(\boldsymbol{B}^{(1,0)}+\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,1)})(s,s),\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(1)}(s)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,s)} + [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,s),\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(2)}(s)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,s)} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, [\boldsymbol{C}^{(1)}(s),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)})(s,s)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,s)} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, [\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s,s),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(2,0)}+\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,1)} + \bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(1,1)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,2)})(s,s)]_{\mathfrak {c}_1^0(s,s)} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, s\, [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,s),\boldsymbol{\nu }^{(1)}(s)]^{22}_{X+\bar{X}} + s\, [\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s),(\boldsymbol{\lambda }^{(1,0)}+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda }}^{(0,1)})(s,s)]^{22}_{X+\bar{X}} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, [\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,0)}(s,s),\boldsymbol{C}^{(1)}(s)]^{22}_{\Xi +\bar{\Xi }} + [(\boldsymbol{B}^{(1,0)}+\boldsymbol{B}^{(0,1)})(s,s),\boldsymbol{C}^{(0)}(s)]^{22}_{\Xi +\bar{\Xi }}\, . \end{eqnarray*} $$
One can obtain any
$\boldsymbol{C}^{(p)}(s)$
one wants by repeating the procedure.

app.title: Appendix B. Composite string fields in open superstring field theory
app.p:
In this appendix we show that the pure-gauge string field G o ( V ) for the open superstring field theory with general A ∞ structure is obtained in a similar way to that given in the heterotic string field theory [ 29 ]. The pure-gauge string field G o ( V o ) is associated with a finite form of the “gauge transformation”
(B1)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \delta _{\delta V_\mathrm{o}} \Psi &=& \pi _1\boldsymbol{L}^\eta _\mathrm{o}\left(\frac{1}{1-\Psi }\otimes \delta V_\mathrm{o}\otimes \frac{1}{1-\Psi }\right) \nonumber \\ &=&\eta \Lambda _\mathrm{o} + L^{\eta }_2(\Psi , \delta V_\mathrm{o}) + L^{\eta }_2(\delta V_\mathrm{o}, \Psi ) + \cdots , \end{eqnarray*} $$
with the infinitesimal parameter δV o , and is obtained by integrating along a straight line connecting 0 and V o that we parameterize as τV o with 0 ≤ τ ≤ 1. Considering that the difference between G o ( τV o + dτV o ) and G o ( τV o ) is an infinitesimal gauge transformation, we obtain the differential equation
(B2)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _{\tau }G_\mathrm{o}(\tau V_\mathrm{o}) = \pi _1\boldsymbol{L}^\eta _\mathrm{o}\left(\frac{1}{1-g G_\mathrm{o}(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes V_\mathrm{o}\otimes \frac{1}{1-g G_\mathrm{o}(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\right), \end{eqnarray*} $$
where we introduced a coupling constant g for convenience.The pure-gauge string field G o ( V o ) corresponds to G o ( τV o ) at τ = 1 and is obtained by solving this differential equation with the initial condition G o (0) = 0. Expanding G o in powers of g as
$G_\mathrm{o}=\sum _{n=0}^\infty g^nG^{(n)}_\mathrm{o}$
, we can sequentially solve the equation. The equation at
$\mathcal {O}(g^0)$
is given by
$\partial _\tau G_\mathrm{o}^{(0)}=\eta V_\mathrm{o}$
and is integrated as G o (0) = τηV o . At
$\mathcal {O}(g)$
, the equation becomes
(B3)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _\tau G_\mathrm{o}^{(1)} = L^\eta _2(\tau \eta V_\mathrm{o}, V_\mathrm{o}) + L^\eta _2(V_\mathrm{o}, \tau \eta V_\mathrm{o}) \end{eqnarray*} $$
and is solved as
(B4)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} G_\mathrm{o}^{(1)} = \frac{\tau ^2}{2}\Big (L^\eta _2(\eta V_\mathrm{o}, V_\mathrm{o}) + L^\eta _2(V_\mathrm{o}, \eta V_\mathrm{o})\Big ). \end{eqnarray*} $$
Similarly, we can find G o up to any order of g we want:
(B5)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} G_\mathrm{o}(V_\mathrm{o}) &=& \eta V_\mathrm{o} + \frac{1}{2}\Big (L^\eta _2(\eta V_\mathrm{o}, V_\mathrm{o}) + L^\eta _2(V_\mathrm{o}, \eta V_\mathrm{o})\Big ) \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, \frac{1}{3}\Big ( L^\eta _3(\eta V_\mathrm{o},\eta V_\mathrm{o}, V_\mathrm{o}) + L^\eta _3(\eta V_\mathrm{o},V_\mathrm{o}, \eta V_\mathrm{o}) + L^\eta _3(V_\mathrm{o}, \eta V_\mathrm{o},\eta V_\mathrm{o})\Big ) \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, \frac{1}{3!}\Big ( L^\eta _2(L^\eta _2(\eta V_\mathrm{o}, V_\mathrm{o}), V_\mathrm{o}) + L^\eta _2(V_\mathrm{o}, \eta V_\mathrm{o},V_\mathrm{o}) \nonumber \\ &&+\,\,L^\eta _2(V_\mathrm{o}, L^\eta _2(\eta V_\mathrm{o}, V_\mathrm{o})) + L^\eta _2(V_\mathrm{o}, L^\eta _2(V_\mathrm{o}, \eta V_\mathrm{o})) \Big ) + \cdots . \end{eqnarray*} $$

In order to find an explicit form of the associated string field
B d
( V o ) ( d = ∂
t
, δ , or Q ), we consider
(B6)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {I}(\tau ) = \pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{L}^\eta _\mathrm{o}\left( \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes B_d(\tau ;V_\mathrm{o},dV_\mathrm{o})\otimes \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\right) - (-1)^d dG_\mathrm{o}(\tau V_\mathrm{o}) \end{eqnarray*} $$
and its τ derivative
(B7)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _\tau \mathcal {I}(\tau ) &=& \pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{L}^\eta _\mathrm{o}\bigg ( \frac{1}{1-G(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes \Big ( \partial _\tau B_d(\tau ;V_\mathrm{o},dV_\mathrm{o})-\mathcal {J}(\tau ) \Big )\otimes \frac{1}{1-G(\tau V_\mathrm{o})} \bigg ) \nonumber \\ &&-\,\, \pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{L}^\eta _\mathrm{o}\bigg ( \frac{1}{1-G(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes \mathcal {I}(\tau )\otimes \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes V_\mathrm{o}\otimes \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(\tau V_\mathrm{o})} \nonumber \\ &&+\,\,(-1)^d\frac{1}{1-G(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes V_\mathrm{o}\otimes \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes \mathcal {I}(\tau )\otimes \frac{1}{1-G_\mathrm{o}(\tau V_\mathrm{o})} \bigg ), \end{eqnarray*} $$
where
(B8)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {J}(\tau ) &=& dV_\mathrm{o} +\pi _1^\mathrm{o}\boldsymbol{L}^\eta _\mathrm{o} \Bigg (\frac{1}{1-G(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes V_\mathrm{o}\otimes \frac{1}{1-G(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes B_d(\tau ;V_\mathrm{o},dV_\mathrm{o})\otimes \frac{1}{1-G(\tau V_\mathrm{o})} \nonumber \\ &&-\,\,(-1)^d\frac{1}{1-G(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes B_d(\tau ;V_\mathrm{o},dV_\mathrm{o})\otimes \frac{1}{1-G(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\otimes V_\mathrm{o}\otimes \frac{1}{1-G(\tau V_\mathrm{o})}\Bigg ). \end{eqnarray*} $$
If
B d
( τ;V o , dV o ) satisfies the differential equation
(B9)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \partial _\tau B_d(\tau ;V_\mathrm{o},dV_\mathrm{o})=\mathcal {J}(\tau ) \end{eqnarray*} $$
with the initial condition
B d
(0; V o , dV o ) = 0, then
$\partial _\tau \mathcal {I}(\tau )$
is proportional to
$\mathcal {I}(\tau )$
with
$\mathcal {I}(0)=0$
, and thus
$\mathcal {I}(\tau )=0$
for all t due to Eq. ( B7 ). Since
$\mathcal {I}(1)=0$
is nothing but the relation in Eq. ( 128 ) characterizing the associated string field, we can obtain the associated field
B d
( V o , dV o ) by solving the differential equation in Eq. ( B9 ). Expanding
$B_d=\sum _{n=0}^\infty g^nB_d^{(n)}$
with scaling G o → gG o , we find that
(B10)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} B_d(V_\mathrm{o},dV_\mathrm{o}) &=& dV_\mathrm{o} + \frac{1}{2}\Big ( L_2^\eta (V_\mathrm{o},dV_\mathrm{o})-L_2^\eta (dV_\mathrm{o},V_\mathrm{o})\Big ) \nonumber \\ &&+\,\, \frac{1}{3}\Big ( L_3^\eta (\eta V_\mathrm{o}, V_\mathrm{o}, dV_\mathrm{o}+)+L_3^\eta (V_\mathrm{o}, \eta V_\mathrm{o}, dV_\mathrm{o})+L_3^\eta (\eta V_\mathrm{o}, V_\mathrm{o}, dV_\mathrm{o}) \nonumber \\ &&-\,\, L_3^\eta (\eta V_\mathrm{o}, dV_\mathrm{o}, V_\mathrm{o}+-)L_3^\eta (dV_\mathrm{o}, \eta V_\mathrm{o}, V_\mathrm{o})-L_3^\eta (\eta V_\mathrm{o}, dV_\mathrm{o}, V_\mathrm{o})\Big ) \nonumber \\ &&+\,\,\frac{1}{3!}\Big ( L_2^\eta (V_\mathrm{o},L_2^\eta (V_\mathrm{o},dV_\mathrm{o})) - L_2^\eta (V_\mathrm{o},L_2^\eta (dV_\mathrm{o},V_\mathrm{o})) \nonumber \\ &&-\,\, L_2^\eta (L_2^\eta (V_\mathrm{o},dV_\mathrm{o}),V_\mathrm{o}) + L_2^\eta (L_2^\eta (dV_\mathrm{o},V_\mathrm{o}),V_\mathrm{o}) \Big ) + \cdots . \end{eqnarray*} $$

fn.p:
In this paper,
$[\cdot,\cdot]$
denotes the graded commutator.
Whether the output is an NS or R string is determined by the space-time fermion number conservation.

Note that the cyclic Ramond number has the upper bound p + 2 ≥ r . We consider
$\boldsymbol{A}_{p+r+1}^{(p)}\big| ^{2r}\equiv 0$
against the outside of this region.

Note that the part of
$\boldsymbol{A}^{(p+1)}(s)$
with a fixed number of inputs contains only a finite number of terms. We can calculate any
$\boldsymbol{A}_{p+r+1}^{(p)}\big| ^{2r}$
with a finite procedure.
The closed string input is counted as 2.
